description: LaCentral is one of my favourite French restaurants. The escargot was wonderful  served with a wonderful bread to dip into the accompanying garlic sauce.  I had the salmon that was perfectly prepared with asparagus and potatoes.   For dessert I had a lemon souffle which was wonderful.  I was with great company.
author: Carl L.

description:
Transport me to Paris!  To start The bread and butter are superb!  We had pate to kick off the lunch followed by salad nicoise AND the Pomme Frites. Devine!!

We will be back!
author: Wendy C.

description:
Really yummy French food! I arrived before my friend and I was a tad suffocated by the staff, who asked me at least 5 times if I wanted to order a drink. However, I realize that they were trying to be attentive.

Once my friend arrived we had a delicious dinner. I started with the onion soup. Ohhh my god. I love a good onion soup, and boy was this delicious. My friend had a salad and she was satisfied. For our main, I got the burger which was really good, and my friend got the filet, which was lovely. They had a really good sauce on the steak, which we both loved. Both meats were cooked to our liking and we enjoyed it very much. 

For dessert, we shared the chocolate mousse which was outstanding. Chocolate loves, rejoice!

Overall, lovely meal and would return again for a special occasion or nice meal.
author: Hannah S.

description:
I really enjoyed my dinner at Central
The atmosphere is vibrant but yet on the quiet side
The service is great and the food is yummy
Their escargot is perfect and so is their onion soup 
Don't forget to eat some creme brûlée as a dessert
author: Jad A.

description:
This place is famous for Mayor Brown, even his photo is on the wall. He has his favorite table too.

The place is exactly like it was when I last visited it 15 years ago! The Maitre'D still has that attitude. The place still old and run down. Lunch still packed with power house folks, a classic spot by China Town entrance, and something about this historical place, just nice to be back once awhile. 

This is 1 of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco, classic French Bistro, famous for their casserole, 15,567 days since the cooked that pot. I didn't enjoy the casserole at all, too much beans, and it was too thick for my taste, I was hoping for more broth.

The Mussels was a generous portion, it was almost 2 lbs, good but no I had it better down the block at Plouf. 

The French Onion Soup was also mediocre. The best was the fish dish special, with the sautéed veggies on the side.

And the Latte was on point, service by the gentleman just started working there a few weeks. He was the highlighted of my lunch meeting.
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
Le Central is a French restaurant offering French cuisine in the heart of San Francisco. We stumbled on this restaurant. When we walked in we were greeted by the bartender behind the bar and he pointed to a table and we proceeded to sit ourselves. We were greeted several minutes later by a server that had little to no knowledge of the menu and wine list. Or he just didn't want to be bothered with talking to us. He was rushed, distracted and was not engaging. 

We started with a CA house cab which was $48 and very tasty. From there we had escargot and sourdough bread. The appetizer was garlicky, buttery and yummy. 

The second course was a butter lettuce salad with nothing exciting to speak of. The third course was a French onion soup ($12) which was very mediocre. For the restaurant being French cuisine, I expected a top notch soup. 

Next, was the main, beef bourgeoisie and the duck confit special. Both dishes were overly salty with very little flavor. 

We ended with a blah experience which we will not be repeating. For San Francisco this restaurant is one I would pass on.
author: Danielle A.

description: Small little restaurant that has been around for a long time. Was there for happy hour and was a good evening with good food. Loved the French music.
author: Sunil R.

description:
We made a reservation here for Valentine's Day dinner. It was pretty easy to make a reservation via open table here since I did book it one week prior to the event. Most places were already booked out. 

This place is pretty small. The tables for two were very crammed to the point where our host had to pull our our table for me to get into the booth. We also sat very close to the tables beside us so don't expect to have privacy or intimate conversations while dining in. Service was decent. The food was pretty tasty! We had the Vday Prime Fixe menu. I ordered the lobster bisque to start off. It was meh. Creamy, pretty tasteless. Bread that came with the meal was super hard/stale. I had the lamb racks as my main. Very juicy and tender, goes well with the sauce. The potato gratin was very delicious as well. Finally, I finished the meal with their creme brûlée. Very generous portion. Tastes great. After all the food prior, I could barely finish dessert. I would consider going back to try other dishes as well.
author: Maggie L.

description:
This place never disappoints. Arrived early for business lunch. I had the salmon bearnaise. It was fantastic. About half pound of moist salmon crispy skin atop roasted cauliflowerets. The sauce was great with the salmon. 

They served baguette with butter as you wait. 

The service was outstanding. Water always filled. 

No Willy Brown that day.
author: Frank T.

description:
Absolutely unexpected gem of a restaurant. 

Quiet and cozy with a relaxing ambience. We savored delicious Happy Hour food at the bar including deviled eggs with roe, perfectly steamed mussels in a light, savory broth and Kronenbourg French beer. 

Our bartender Sean, a native San Franciscan, entertained us with stories of San Francisco's movers and shakers, which was the perfect accompaniment to our meal. 

We will definitely be returning again.
author: Jenny S.

description:
What a wonderful place, unfortunate that I cannot eat here every day! In a city full of new and fly-by-night eateries, I rely more and more on the classic institutions and Le Central is exactly that. I know every time that I visit that I can expect a great cocktail, a delicious meal, and an atmosphere that for me has become a home-away-from-home.

Get a martini or a glass of Montagny, order the escargots or the mussels. And don't forget to try the cassoulet, it'll change your life!
author: Myles K.

description:
Meh... last time here was 20 years ago when I worked FIDI and I've told my wife for years the best Cassoulet in the world, better than we've had in Lyon, France... yeah, not so much anymore... The Steak au Poivre literally did not have peppercorns but rather was a brown gravy and mushrooms... hey I wasn't born yesterday and I didn't just fall off the turnip truck, I know Steak au Poivre, and this was no Steak au Poivre... 

The onion soup was tasty as was our reasonably priced bottle of french red... service was goo.b But we cannot recommend.
author: Kenneth F.

description:
I'll admit, I wasn't psyched to come here for a group dinner a few weeks ago. There are so many new, trendy restaurants in San Francisco, and French food isn't usually high on my list. But I was very pleasantly surprised by Le Central!

The atmosphere is warm and feels a lot like the bistros you'd see in the streets of Paris--it was fun to feel transported when we walked in. They also have a good happy hour deal on house wines but you have to order it at the bar, can't get it at your table!

The cassoulet was definitely the standout. It's quite heavy--I split it with another person and it was still a lot of food. I'd actually suggest three people go for it and then get sides. But the flavors were excellent, it was comforting, and not something you find at most restaurants in San Francisco. We also had the butter lettuce salad which was delicious, the french fries which were really good, and the escargot because when at a French restaurant, go big or go home. Flavors on everything were solid, the dishes were well prepared, and and it was great for a group of eight.
author: Sophie S.

description: This place looks dated and overpriced but the food is really good and the service is personable. Great for a quiet catch up or business meeting. Be ready to spend a bunch, though.
author: Julie N.

description: I am reviewing Le Central based soley on the happy hour. I'm giving it 5 stars for atmosphere, friendliness, and a great French wine for $5. Sometimes a girl just needs a place to stop in for a glass of wine and feel welcome! This will definitely become a regular spot for me!
author: Sheila K.

description:
Went here for restaurant week. The French Onion Soup was pretty good but we came for their Cassoulet which was mediocre at best. It was incredibly bland.

Giving it another star for the ambiance as it does feel like a little slice of Paris and I could see myself coming back for a glass of wine at happy hour.
author: Lucy D.

description:
Probably the worst French restaurant in SF or worst restaurant period.
Starting from the welcoming or should I say the NO welcoming: hi, table for one ? When I walked with my wife and son !??:)
Maybe a "good afternoon how can I help you" wouldn't hurt...
The food here is so basic and boring I don't know where to start. So I opted for their very famous Cassoulet. Big mistake.
This over cooked, tasteless, dry and over priced little casserole of beans with a quarter piece of sausage, and a few shredded duck meat and lamb was so disappointing it made me décideront write my first negative Yelp review.
My son was sitting next to the kitchen doors where there is almost half an inch of dust next to his face. Lovely.
The waiter also was on top of his form, giving me lecture on how to order Cote Rôtie to go with Cassoulet when all I asked was a glass of pairing red. I dunno maybe Cahors (Malbec) or even Bordeaux was more appropriate and in my budget. But no he said the Cote Rotie at $19/glass is what I need because he knows and I don't!!!
Lovely again.
What's really funny is that I ate here 23 years ago and it was already disgusting. I'm not masochist but just wanted to give a second chance...
There won't be another one.
Bonne chance to all futur patrons there.
author: Laurent G.

description:
A solid place for French food in the heart of San Francisco's downtown. I have seen the outside Le Central for decades now driving on Bush Street heading back to the East Bay in my car but this was the first time I had walked from the Montgomery Street BART station and eaten at Le Central and it was all thanks to San Francisco Restaurant Week. A friend and I wanted to meet up to commemorate another great year and so we looked on the website to see what affordable options that were out there that sounded good but also didn't break our wallets and we found a really solid option with Le Central.   

Upon entry I noticed that Le Central could resemble a local watering hole in any American city or small local restaurant in Paris. It was cozy and warm without coming across as too pretentious. There was a huge long bar on one side of a double sided restaurant with small two top tables and booths abound. As for their menu they seem to have a number of dishes that best represent the best of what Parisian flair has to offer. Their San Francisco Restaurant Week menu best exemplifies some of the dishes they serve at a fairly decent price point. Where else could you get Escargot, Beef Bourguignon, and a Chocolate Mousse for only forty dollars total? No where in San Francisco outside of that ten day period every January.

Since this was SF Restaurant Week and we were here to take advantage of the meal deal they were offering up I had to go with the traditional Onion Soup Gratinee with a boatload of Gruyere cheese and herb croutons this starter was just the way I like my French Onion Soup, gooey and cheesy.  As for my second course I debated between the Beef Bourguignon and the Cassoulet. Against my better judgement I went with the Cassoulet, with its white bean stew topped with duck confit, shreds of lamb and pork and served with one half of a Toulouse sausage. I felt that the dish, although well prepared, was filled with too many beans for my liking and not enough meat protein. Thankfully, there was plenty of baguette bread to go with my bean stew because I was in serious search for a starch to go with my main course and the beans weren't doing it. The dish does go well with the Cotes du Rhone red wine that I was able to purchase at the discount price of 5 dollars thanks to it being Restaurant Week. My dining companion got the Petrale Sole topped with lemon-butter-caper sauce, and served with cauliflower gratin and fingerling potatoes. She loved it and I had a small bite and loved how lightly pan fried the fish was. To finish off our meal, we each ordered both dessert options I liked the Mousse au Chocolat which was a chocolate mousse topped with both a creme chantilly and two rolled gaufrette pastries. But the real delight was the Souffle Glacee which was a chilled lemon souffle and berry compote. It was a light dessert without being overly sweet.

I liked Le Central which of course is centrally located in between the Financial District and the entryway to Chinatown. An uncomplicated French Bistro the middle of the chaotic hustle and bustle of the city. Their menu deals for San Francisco Restaurant Week were solid for the price and hope they got more business than usual because of it. If I'm ever in the area again, I'll be sure to stop by and sample some of their other dishes on their regular menu, all of which sounded rather delicious. Merci Le Central!
author: Jason F.

description: Love love love Le Central. I ate here many times when it first opened in 1974. Still takes you back to France every meal. Classic and traditional French bistro fare. Excellent pate, lovely Belgian endive. Service was appropriate for slow food and charming bistro as ambiance. Although we arrived too late to take advantage of it, their happy hour looked excellent. If you love traditional French bistro food (and know what that actually is) you will love Le Central, too.
author: Jordana G.

description:
Checked out Le Central on Bush St near Grant Ave in SF.  It's pretty old and not much buzz so I really shouldn't have gone.  I'm not a huge fan of French anyways.

They brought out butter and then cold, hard baguettes - boo.  Nobody especially me wants cold, hard bread!

Escargot only 6 in a big puddle of garlic & butter $12.50.  Tasted ok, nothing special.  I dipped my cold, hard bread into the butter/garlic so it was a tiny bit better.

special soup of the day was Carrot Butternut Squash Soup in a bowl $9.5 - tasted ok.  It does get cold pretty fast though.

Lamb dinner $36.50 was pretty good & too expensive.  some seriously small lamb chops, some scoop of potato gratin, tiny amount of eggplant, 3 broccoli spears.

Creme Brulee $8.5 - not as crackly as it should be, just ok.

B. got some booze - glass of Sazerac $12 and glass of Cotes du Rhone $10 - don't know if he liked it but drank it all up.  

Charged it.  Meh overpriced dinner.
author: Ann L.

description: Fantastic service. Everyone makes you feel so welcome. The music is fantastic!  Food fabulous!!
author: Marc T.

description: I had a great time at Le Central.  I ordered a glass of Sauv. Blanc but the bartender offered that I could taste their happy hour white Bourdeux which was only $5 per glass at the time.  It was wonderful, so I opted for that.  I also had a glass of Sancerre later on in my meal and it was also a lovely glass of wine. I ordered half a dozen oysters and they were dainty and fresh, just how they outta be. The sauteed Dayboat scallops for my entree were perfectly cooked, atop a luscious pea puree with some perfectly cooked petite veg on the side and small spoonful of a decadent cauliflower gratin that was to die for. The dessert selection was calling my name but I'd reached an elegant sufficiency so I had a decaf coffee and called it a night. Magnifique, can't wait to go back.
author: Emma H.

description:
2 Stars - for food. It was forgettable. We've had much better french food in the city.

0 - Star - for service. We were a party of 13, I chose the place because it is easily accessible for everyone coming from work. We were there for both happy hour and dinner. Some of us  started ordering happy hour drinks at the bar but then the Manager rudely told us that we cannot order happy hour drinks anymore because we had reservation at the dining area. Hmmmmm, we are regular San Franciscan diners and we are very familiar about having happy hour drinks at the bar vs dining area. Fair enough . We understand this and it's common practice but to be told that we cannot be served anymore in the bar area is simply ridiculous. We usually run up a bill close to $800- $1,000 because we start with happy hour and stay for dinner .The Manager made a big mistake making assumptions that we are only there for "happy hour". The place was empty on a Friday night and they should have been more accommodating instead of being uptight about the whole thing. We would have ordered couple of appetizers, a bottle of champagne and desserts after but we didn't because of the cold reception. P.S. - on top of that they messed up our bill too! Added something we did not order. Never again!
author: Carrie F.

description: Dropped by for happy hour but ended up ordering from the dinner menu. Ordered the staple and was not disappointed. The steak tartare was not salty like in most places. The beef was fresh and can afford not to be overly seasoned. Escargot was also amazing. Kirsten, the bartender, was friendly and provided good service. I can see myself coming back for the $5 cocktails and the food.
author: Rori G.

description: UNREMARKABLE in every single way. We had the roasted chicken and the cassoulet, both were bland, completely unseasoned, and lacking any flavor at all. And this place passes on the 5% SFEM tax to customers as well! Go elsewhere!
author: Brennan J.

description:
This SF institution is the dining room of who's who and we enjoy returning time and again! As three generation SF natives, we love Le Central! It is classic, old school....You know what you are going to get! Consistent authentic French Cuisine!

Starters:
French onion soup 
Steak tartare
Clams
Crab cake
Escargots 
Entrees:
Filet Mignon
Roast chicken with pomme frites
Scallops
French Lamb
Signature Cassoulet 
Dessert:
Soufflé 
Apple Tart
Tiramisu
Berry crumble 

Owners Anthony and his daughter are great at front and back of the house! Paul and Scott always a pleasure to have on the floor!
author: Sharon S.

description:
Casulet served cold and had to be sent back to the microwave. It consisted of beans and what looked like an Oscar Meyer breakfast sausage floating in it, and not very much of it at that. The moulles were also cold by the time they arrived.
The is Resturant is a shadow of its former glory.
author: Greg S.

description: What HAPPENED to this place?! It used to be great. Hadn't been there for a few years until last night, when we had one of the worst dinners we've ever had in a restaurant. Food, drink, and service were all terrible. There is barely room to walk between the bar stools and the EMPTY tables. What HAPPENED?!
author: Laura R.

description:
There are many French Restaurants near Bush Street and this place is a classic.
It is simple and not upscale and  all  of my 4 experiences have been fine. I have not been in two years but would try this place again when I am in SF and in the area.
author: Dan R.

description: partner took me here for a dinner date because he knew i liked french onion soup honestly all the food was bland and i feel like they judged us because we was young and didn't take us seriously
author: Donnae K.

description: I ordered the french onion soup and their "signature" cassoulet; I woke up with such severe stomach pain that I literally almost went to the hospital because I was worried I had appendicitis. 0/10 would recommend.
author: Ryan N.

description: Don't be discouraged by the whiners.  For 30+ years Le Central has consistently made me happy.  New and trendy are part of life, but old school and genuine are every bit as important to me.  When was the last time you walked into a restaurant after a three year absence and were welcomed warmly and told that you had been missed?  I told the waiter that he was mistaking me for someone else, and he replied, "No, not at all.  Would you like your usual?"  And he nailed my order right down to the martini!  I call Le Central warm and friendly, and DELICIOUS every time.  Can't wait to get back to SF just for Le Central.
author: Michael M.

description:
We went to La Central during SF Restaurant Week and had the prix fixe menu. 

The food was mostly delicious, but the restaurant was crowded. We both had the onion soup and it was fantastic, would definitely recommend. 

My husband had the cassolette and wasn't blown away by it, he found it a little bland. I had the beef bourguignon which was very good, especially the mashed potato. The serving seemed slightly on the smaller side but I ended up not being able to eat it all. 

For dessert Husdude had the Soufflé which was excellent and I had the chocolate mousse which was very good but I don't think there's actually that much difference between a decent chocolate mousse and a really good one so I wished I'd picked the Soufflé instead. 

The bar was out of one of the ingredients for the cocktail I wanted to order and the cocktail menu was far from extensive so that was disappointing. I later heard the waiter tell someone else that they had a full bar but when I'd tried to ask for something off menu similar to what I'd wanted the waiter was entirely unhelpful. 

The tables were extremely close together so if you're looking for an intimate restaurant for a date this is not really appropriate, unless you're ok with being intimate with the folks at the tables on either side of you as well! Overall this is a decent restaurant with good food but you definitely come for the food rather than the ambiance and don't feel inclined to linger.
author: Teegan L.

description: I don't understand the hype. Decent food but the venue is dated and not in a cool retro way.
author: Rosy P.

description: I was meeting friends from Mexcio who were visiting SF and we decided to go to Le Central.  We had a fabulous time.  The cassoulet was incredible.  Everyone enjoyed all of the entrees, and the two appetizers we shared were great as well.  Staff was very attentive and we enjoyed a great evening there.  Would definitely go back.
author: Ken E.

description:
Even though I have lived in SF for many many years, I had never been to this FABULOUS RESTAURANT... People, GO, GO, GO!!!  There are several clubs that went or go all the time. EX-Mayor Willie Brown goes to lunch there almost everyday and we got to sit at The Famous Herb Caen table as he was a regular there,.There was nice music playing in the back ground and was soft enough to be heard and the room was not overly noisy.. You could still talk and carry on a good conversation.
The service was fabulous and the food was beyond exquisite...The escargot was perfect and the country pate' was beyond words. Two of had the Streak Tartare and I had the Cassoulet, and it was beyond delicious,Seasoned perfectly. It was very rich, so I got to take almost half home and get it for lunch tomorrowYEA!!!!!~!~!~ One of the best I have ever eaten. we had two desserts to share , the Mousse au chocolaté and the Tiramisu... both,  exquisite . I highly recommend this restaurant and be dining there a lot!!!!
Stefn W... San Francisco
author: Stephen W.

description: wife and I went to set menu as part of restaurant week.  as so many others have said, the Cassoulet was to die for but so was the Beef Bourguignon!  the appetizers Onion Soup Gratinée was OK but Escargots de Bourgogne was over the top... and the Souffle Glacee was exceptional
author: William T.

description:
A strong 3 stars, but probably not a 4th.

I had a business dinner at a table for 8 here one night, followed (coincidentally) by a social lunch for 2 the next day, so I saw both types of experience.

In all, a serviceable and cozy French restaurant with moderate prices.  As it is in downtown SF, it should get no easy grades - San Francisco is a sophisticated city with many good restaurants across the spectrum of food, so standards by which this restaurant is to be graded are high.  It is sufficient.

For dinner, there were escargots (average), oysters (above average), and scallops (average) for me.  I did also have a ginger/carrot soup (above average).  This was all chased by several shared bottles of white burgundy, which I found cold and charming of course, but the vintage escapes me and I did not handle the wine list, so I can't comment on their wine selections.

For lunch, I had a filet mignon plate (above average).

As for service, it was adequate and there were no disappointments - particularly for the dinner.  The lunch experience involved a waiter that was not terribly present or involved in making sure we understood the menu, but then again lunch is a more hurried affair and he was certainly not guilty of any high crimes or misdemeanors.

I would have gone to a 4th star if my girlfriend was with me, but then again I get slutty with stars in reviewing restaurants on Yelp if my girlfriend happens to have been part of the meal.
author: chris s.

description:
This restaurant is stuck in time.

It's a shame because the food is actually pretty good. The french onion soup is solid with it's ooey gooey gruyere. I ordered the Rack of Lamb Persillé and was delighted that they gave me such a hefty portion of ribs (a full rack vs. usually getting a half rack at other French restaurants for the same price). They were succulently medium rare and went great with the creamy potato gratin. My bf got the beef bourguignon and it was also good (I was practically picking off his plate). As recommended my our waitress, we got the chocolate mousse for dessert. The presentation could have been a little fancier (kind of looked like a scoop of poop on a plate), but it satisfied. Still wish I got the tiramisu or creme caramel instead though. Aside from that, the staff was very nice and accommodating. We called ahead and got there barely before closing, and they still waited for us and were very attentive.

Back to my first remark... this place needs some serious renovation. I didn't look at any pictures of the location beforehand and ate here because the menu looked promising, but I was REALLY disappointed that it looked like a diner inside. Even though I was very satisfied with my meal, I was conflicted because the interior lacked ambience and just didn't match my expectations. I was even feeling chilly! I don't think I will return because there are other French restaurants at a similar price point that are simply nicer and more intimate inside. Sorry.
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: We came as a group of 6. We first came for Happy Hour, which is only available in the bar, and then stayed for dinner at a table. Happy Hour was great. First of all it was available on a Saturday so it's not just during the week, and it went until 7pm! We had wine, brie, oysters, frites, and had a great time. It's an awesome happy hour deal with lots of yummy food to snack on for cheap! Dinner, on the other hand, was not as impressive. There was nothing wrong really, it just wasn't as good as the happy hour in my opinion. The French Onion Soup is made with gruyere cheese which smells so bad. I think a couple of their other dishes are also made with this cheese, because we kept getting whiffs of this funky smell when certain plates went past us. The soup I got was mostly bread and cheese, with very little actual soup. I got the impression the rest of our party felt similarly about their orders...good, but not great or worth the priciness. So in conclusion, I would definitely come back here and recommend Le Central for happy hour, but I would probably choose a different spot for dinner.
author: Nicole D.

description:
Do not waste your time, terrible service, terrible food. The waiter actually came back and asked my boyfriend and I why our tip was so bad. Who does that!? The food tasted like it was a week old, our waiter was god awful and had no social graces and it was so damn expensive and we were served food that I wouldn't even feed my dog. 

I was waiting for Gordon Ramsey to come around the corner, this place could easily be on kitchen nightmares. Honest to god, do not eat here.
author: Elise G.

description: This was the only spot in the area we could find that served escargot. It was garlicky and delicious. We loved the French onion soup and the sea bass tasted great. It's clear that this spot is a neighborhood hangout with regulars that come frequently.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Of course, Le Central's kitchen is fine.

Unfortunately, there is more to dining that just the food.

To put this as simply as possible, I booked at table for eight for New Year's Eve.  The reservation was made a full four days in advance.  When I arrived with my out-of-town guests, all of whom were of a sylphlike slenderness, the restaurant attempted to seat us at a makeshift table set in the middle of the dining room that was best suited for six adults at best.  When we asked to be moved to a reasonably sized table, the staff kept us waiting for more than 20 minutes.  

Now, normally, we are willing to cut our home town restaurants a large amount of slack during the holidays.  HOWEVER, in the dining room there were many tables on the banquette that could have been moved together immediately to accommodate us.  Why were they not?  Because the staff was more worried about a party of seven that had not arrived - and several other parties of two that had not arrived - than they were with the party of eight standing directly in front of them.  

Finally, after three reminders that we were still waiting, the staff did, indeed, move the banquette tables together to accommodate us.  And they did not do it cheerfully, nor even politely.

And guess what?  The party of seven never showed, nor did many of the other parties the staff were expecting.  During the entire meal, there was no line at the door.  Un tien vaut mieux que deux tu l'auras, Le Central.

By the way, our tab came to $1,200 for the party of eight, so its not like we were a poor risk.

As regular customers, we expected that Le Central would be a solid place to bring out-of-town guests in terms of both food and service.  It was an incredibly irritating and embarrassing experience.  I won't be back, and considering how often I have eaten at Le Central over the years, this is a strong statement.

As an aside, the wine list, in terms of the selection of French wines by the bottle, is poor given Le Central's focus.
author: Patricia P.

description: What a shame. The chef retired from this great bistro and now whoever took over for him has completely screwed it up. They've lost 2/3 of the menu items, half the staff, and the poor waiters as well as the other owner are completely overworked. I was told they hired a "consultant" who told them to rework the place. What a nightmare. This bistro has been the go-to spot for power brokers and those in the know for years. But you could also go have a nice quiet romantic dinner there with your wife, with great service and reliable very good food. If some newbie thinks they are going to turn it into a millenial hotspot they are idiots. It was never that kind of place and never will be. This change will just drive it into the ground. They even changed their famous roast chicken. WTF??? Bring back the onion tart!
author: Earl P.

description:
This was enjoyable and the feel of the restaurant was similar to New York.
However, note, that means the restaurant is tight... they had to pull the tables out for us to get into our booths seats! Getting to and from the bathroom was difficult as well.

Food: Amazing! 
Escargots de Bourgogne - yes! 
Cassoulet - my first ever, it was heavy, and creamy!
Dessert I couldn't care for, not recommended...

Service is where it falls short. The person who served us was rather rude and I felt hurried... Not that the restaurant was full at all during our dinner.
author: Amy H.

description: Loved the intimate ambiance and my lunch was delish. I wanted something light and decided on the roasted beets and the smoked trout with capers and onions served with a healthy side of potato salad. Damn, that was good! I loved, loved the beets; the smoked salmon (with a little horseradish dressing) was very tasty but their potato salad rocked. Hold on now, the best part of my meal: Hendricks grin gimlet, straight up, very, very cold, dry. Oh my the bartender knew what he was doing. First I saw the tiny martini Glass and my face fell until I saw the ice bucket with a carafe worth the rest of the gimlet. Love this place. Thanks to Joyce & Elvin Crum for the suggestion. I missed my friend former Mayor Willie Brown my minutes; next time....
author: Robbie B.

description:
The Escargots de Bourgogne were just amazing, and I was pleased to find Choucroute and Céleri Rémoulade on the menu.

It was a long time ago though.
author: Bruno P.

description: I enjoyed my evening here. We were able to get a reservation during restaurant week the day of. Our waiter was very accommodating and the food came out in a timely manner. The food for the restaurant week menu was quite good and there was a lot of variety. I must say my favorite part was dessert. Their tiramisu was amazing. I would come back to try the rack of lamb sometime.
author: Lynn T.

description:
I came to Le Central because of their cassoulet. I had actually planned on making this dish myself, but I thought I should try the classic French version first. While it was good, I could see there where a lot of additional ingredients I would have added. But then it wouldn't have been a classic cassoulet. I'd give it 3.5 stars. By the way, that dish could easily be shared by two. 

What takes them to 4 stars is the service and a superb apple tart. If you go there for dinner you must order the apple tart for dessert. I plan to go back just for the apple tart.
author: Anthony W.

description:
I wandered in here the other night, surprised that the reviews on Yelp,were so lukewarm as I had a really good experience, from the people that I met to the the food to the friendliness of the bartender.

I sat at the bar as I had no reservation but that didn't matter as I was warmly greeted and shown the specials of the day along with the happy hour specials.

I ordered 6 oysters off the happy hour menu and then the chicken and pomme frites off the regular menu.  A nice pour of the house Cab and I was a happy girl.

 The food came up quickly and was quite good- simple in its approach but very tasty.  And with the old school feel of this place, I almost felt like I was at a small bistro on the back streets of Paris.

Le Central is not a fancy place but rather a small neighborhood place where people seemingly know each other and are warmly greeted upon entering.  I could have stayed at the bar all night talking to the locals and enjoying the various wines that lined the bar.

But an early morning beckoned me so it was back to my hotel I went, but my tummy was full and step a little lighter from a nice evening out.
author: Carol K.

description:
Made reservation via Opentable for last Wed at 7:15pm, a bufday celebration. Arrived ontime and was told my name is not on their system, host even showed me their list. So i had to reserve the next available 7:30pm slot. Dinner went smooth, our waiter was fast in ordering our two glass of Zin and numerous appetizers of crabcake hmmhmm good, filet mignon tartare(this was very bland), clams in white wine(very very juicy), beet salad(tasted a lot better than it looks) and for entree to share was the yummy scallops(chef plated separtely yet still a huge portion, thank you!) So full, we said no to dessert =]
next day, i get an email from opentable, restaurant claimed that i did not honor my reservation. i emailed back of course and received 100points only...argh!!! Please give me back my 1000 points! =/
author: Vee V.

description: Ideal restaurant for group and friends of course couple too. This French restaurant's service is great and food is nice too. Not too formal, and definitely good restaurant and worth to try.
author: Unyo N.

description:
Excellent food and great vibe and people!
The New York steak the wine and the dessert was great!
Easy 5
author: Ben R.

description:
This is the second time we have come to this restaurant for SF Restaurant Week.  
This year it was somewhat crazier on account of the march in support for women after DT's inaug.  

Our waiter was super nice and took excellent care of us.  The food was great and the desserts superb.  My favorite this evening was the French Onion Soup. It was perfect.  Prepared just like it should be.  Wish I could afford it more often.
author: Emilia G.

description:
We took our intern out for his birthday and chose Le Central. He is French so we figured, why not. We made reservations easily and were seated in a nice 4 top table in the side room. We ordered the cheese plate $16 which was good. We also ordered the crab cake to share which was great. It was breaded perfectly and had chunks of crab. I chose the scallops for my entree, which came on a bed of spinach with tomatoes and a nice creamy sauce. It hit the seafood spot. For dessert we shared the tart tartine, which was just okay. The cream was way too sweet. 

I will have to drag my bf back here for dinner since it is a nice frenchy romantic place.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
I was treated to a special Christmas luncheon by my financial advisor on 12/10 and La Central was amazing! How often do you walk into a restaurant and shake hands with the ex SF Mayor Willie Brown? He was very friendly and obviously treats La Central like a second home. The waitstaff was very welcoming and Scott our server was on point! He was very helpful and took care of our group with ease.  

My first course was the escargot and it was the BEST I've ever had! Very tender, garlicky, and perfectly buttery little delights! My second course was the blood sausage and frites. The blood sausage was smooth and seasoned amazingly. It was very rich, but I couldn't stop eating them with the flavorful apples. Lastly, I enjoyed the creme brûlée and it was by far one of the best I've ever had! 

I can't wait until the next time I get treated to come to lunch here. It's like family here and the food is incredible. Great San Francisco institution!
author: Karen C.

description: My husband and I were fortunate enough to travel to Toulouse last year., home to the Cassoulet. Therefore it may be unfair to compare but what this restaurant serves is not a real French Cassoulet.  Le Central's version of this dish is really more of a stew.  It was ok, like the rest of their food.  It was not impressive to me at all by any measure.  There are other places in the Bay Area to eat good quality French food.
author: Daly D.

description: Third visit for lunch - prior lunch and dinner occasions. This is a classic in San Francisco, has been around I think over 30 years, and it is as old style class as you get, from the decor to the pretty classic French dishes - no nouvelle cuisine here - to Willie Brown sitting at a table for lunch today (I kid you not). The service is very good, they shake good martinis (from my dinner) and today I had the Bordeoux Blanc by the glass, $8. The food is solid, but not the best. Today I had the pork chops, and it was good, but not well bonded with the sauce, they were probably cooked separately, then the sauce poured on top. So, 3 stars for food, 4 stars for ambiance, service, decor, and character, makes it a 4 star in my mind
author: Massimo M.

description:
Proper, near perfect escargot. Nothing unusual or innovative; just right. It was just an escargot-kind-of-night and I went grazing from one French place to the next. 

Nice background jazz, good service, laid back... Nice!

Critique: turn down the lights a bit for a sexier setting. 

I will definitely return to sample more froggy fare from Central.
author: Martin S.

description: Very French, great food and cozy atmosphere. I eat at the bar and at a table . Always great service and delish food.
author: Cecilia D.

description: Had a birthday lunch with my wife here today and it was very good. I had the burger and she had the green beans and it really hit the spot. The beef was exceptional and the fries were hot and tasty, we will definitely be back on our next trip to S.F.
author: Bill S.

description: There was a time when both I and Le Central were young.  It was remarkably good at that juncture in our respective lives. Then I left the area for a couple of decades. Neither I nor Le Central are young anymore--and one of us has lost their mojo.  Le Central's roast chicken was once a masterpiece--juicy, crisp, a bit salty--a worthy competitor to French cooking.  Now, it's a sadly small, shriveled and dry bird.  Certainly not one to attract me back.  Note: In the midst of my exile a colleague and I were in SF and I enthusiastically led him to dinner at Le Central.  It was embarrassingly mediocre. I had thought that maybe that was just a bad night; almost no one was there so maybe the chef had left the chief bus person in charge.  Today's visit confirmed that the decline is real.
author: Charles E.

description:
3.5 stars...used to be more.

There is a certain ambiance that I love about Le Central. Yes I have been eating here since the cassoulet was only a thousand days old...

Where else can you bump into Willie Brown, Harry De Wildt, or Wilkes Bashford (WHO??)....I'm gettin old...yawn.

Love their Celery root remolaude, onion soup, and the famous Roast Chicken and pomme fritte....the aforementioned Cassoulet is also good.

Service is okay and the food is still pretty good...in a bubble...but when you compare Le Central to what else is out there it is not the same.

Never the less if you really want to step into the wayback machine with Mr Peabody and Sherman (  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KEm_8m4or7M ) and see what San Francisco was like in the 70's have  lunch at Le Central.......IT IS A TRUE CLASSIC!
author: David G.

description:
Went here for lunch, while the service was friendly and accommodating, I found the food to be generally way overpriced.  There are many better places at this price point I would recommend instead.

My meal focused on the appetizers since the main courses didn't seem to offer much bang for the buck.  Chicken and french fries: $24.  Cassoulet for $28.  Salad nicoise for $20.  All of these "peasant" dishes at the price of high end plates was ridiculous. The rest of the entrees were $25-$35 each.  

We got bread and butter as a freebie at the table.  The bread was delicious, but the butter was cold and hard.  I expected room temperature butter at this price point.

I had the crab cakes, these were good and stuffed with crab.  

A friend had a burrata and heirloom tomato salad, that would have been excellent if it was tomato season.  But it is not tomato season, so the tomatoes were not in season or local and were mediocre.  

All of the food was under seasoned.  The salt and pepper shakers were very much en vogue in 1974, basic chain hotel grade salt and old ground pepper.

Le Central was probably great in 1974.  In 2016 there are a lot of better places with higher quality ingredients at the same price.
author: Jame E.

description:
Charming little French place with a good location.  I have now been here several times and the food is always great.  I almost always get the filet.  It has a black peppercorn sauce and it is probably one of the best in the city.  The creme brulee is a nice way to finish a decadent evening!  Definitely will be returning.

They are on open table which is a plus!
author: Jax B.

description:
Good service, food is nothing to write home about. It's just ok. My husband ordered the cassoulet over which, there is much hype, according to fellow Yelpers and the countdown in the restaurant over how many days they'll been serving it. Here is something to consider: the traditional REAL French cassoulet never, EVER has lamb. I asked the server if it tasted "gamey" , he kindly offered me a taste, which to me was quite gamey. I had the salmon, again nothing special. 

Service was good for the most part and we were able to sit there 30 minutes earlier. 

I much rather skip the drive to SF and go to the Girl and the Fig in Sonoma. Now THAT place a really good French food :-)
author: Marie I.

description: We ate at Le Central during Restaurant Week after not having eaten there for decades. The cassoulet remains the reason to go. It's flavorful and authentic; other San Francisco versions seem not nearly as rich as Le Central's. I enjoyed it greatly. My wife enjoyed her salmon, as well, but did not find it extraordinary. Desserts were quite good. The bar area where we ate is cramped but the adjoining room looks much more comfortable. Service was more than adequate, although our poor server had too many tables to manage. Recommended, especially if you enjoy cassoulet.
author: Mike R.

description: Wife and I went here for vDay. It was really tasty and they sat us even though we were 15 minutes early for our reservation. The food was really tasty. They lost one star because my Fillet wasn't cooked as ordered and it was placed on top of a piece of soggy "toast". The bread didn't have to be there and reminded me of Wonderbread. Luckily that was such a small portion of the whole.
author: Jm C.

description:
I visited Le Central last Friday night for the first time and had a really wonderful experience. The ambiance was great, the location was convenient, and the food was  the best French cuisine I have had in San Francisco. I even ate escargot for the first time, and was pleasantly surprised.

I arrived at 6:30 to meet some friends after work, and was immediately seated on the bar side of the restaurant. The waiter quickly came over and brought a cute blackboard with chalk-written specials of the day which he placed on the table. We ordered a bottle of the house pinot noir, and began looking over the menu.

We ordered:
Herb crusted goat cheese
Escargot
Duck Rilletes
Cassoulet
Rack of Lamb Persilles
Dayboat Scallops Provencale

The food was amazing. I personally ordered the escargot and the cassoulet, both of which I had never had before, and they were delicious. The escargot was tender, and in an amazing garlic pesto type sauce, and the cassoulet came in a cute little orange pot and was the most amazing stew I have ever had. and I had the chance to try all of my friends plates, and they were were all on-point.

The waiter even came over and poured us more wine to refill our glasses on the house. It's little touches like that which really make a restaurant special, and this restaurant is definitely very special.

Thanks for a great dining experience, Le Central.
author: Jamie J.

description:
Exhausted after walking through Chinatown, we literally came upon this place as we crossed the street on the way back to our hotel. We settled in with wonderful French bread, chilled sweet butter and a couple of glasses of white wine. We split a cassoulet, and it was magnificent. Duck confit, lamb sausage, cooked with white beans in a little covered pot of goodness.  This seems to be a regular place for locals.  They've been open for 39 years and use a little bit of the previous day's base to start  the next day's batch of cassoulet every day for the past 14,000+ days.

Everyone seemed to know our waiter, who according to the lovely couple sitting next to us, has been their waiter for the 30 years they've been coming, always sitting them at the same table.

Man, I love it when I find places like this.
author: Roger Y.

description: Oridnary, service very basic, steal tartare, where was the egg? creme caramel looked like it had been made days beforehand
author: Kym H.

description: A taste of real french food!! I have never been to France but my girlfriends father is french who has been teaching me about great french meals. I love french deserts! I am a meat person so I tried the Pot Pie which was amazing. All the dishes on the table looked delicious and yum! The atmosphere of the place really complimented the food. It's petit!! I enjoyed trying new restaurant in the city and I most def recommend you try it too!
author: Nuno V.

description:
I extended my trip to catch up with a very wonderful friend of mine I hadn't seen in two years, asking him to suggest a new lunch hotspot he might know of, where we could kill an afternoon. After all, not only is he a well connected business name in this town, he is usually on top of everything that goes on in several major cities he lives in throughout the world.. So it came as a huge surprise when I received the e mail confirmation from him about a place that's been around forever. 

Le Central is the westcoast's answer to "21" ( NY). When it comes to power brokerage, these places are not really about food but have everything to do with the scene. Five minutes inside and I understood it immediately. There should be a venue like this in all name brand cities, (and there is!).  This is a restaurant that offers two levels of front of house membership - Do They Know You vs. Who Are You? Weigh this carefully when reading the reviews here. Which group do you think has a happier experience?

I'm from that last great bistro generation - the one where your dad's table was ready no matter what time he arrived, where the entire staff made things work no matter how crazed the room was, even moving lessor constellations to other tables so their best customers were taken care of. This was before Restaurant.com, Restaurant Week, the passive aggressiveness of internet reviews, online democracy. I'm talking about a time when players were PLAYERS, and trusted their Maitre' D with all the big secrets. A time when a house manager knew what deals were going down just based on the seating chart in his room.

Oh yeah. I almost forgot. The Sea Bass was great...... So what!
author: Gene D.

description:
Solid three stars. (Service 3/5, Food 4/5, and Ambiance 2.5/5) and I came here for dinner Saturday at 8pm for Restaurant Week.  I picked this restaurant over the others because the prix fixe menu actually offered their signature dishes at a good deal, which is not the case for all restaurants that participate. I'm not sure why the reviews are so bad on service. We came 15 minutes before our reservation, and was seated right away. We actually weren't too fond of the spot, and the hostess was kind enough to accommodate by moving us to another table. Our server was also very sweet. He tended to us, but not in an annoying way. I took some points off because he kept mixing up our dishes as he served them and only gave one of us water, when we both had asked. The comments regarding how dated the restaurant is are pretty accurate. It's not terrible, but the old lighting fixtures and dated surroundings make you think what the kitchen is like. I'm sure it needs a general face lift.

Food was good.  We got the following:
Escargot--very tender and seasoned well. perhaps a little salty, but great for dipping bread
French onion soup--I honestly don't know what good French onion soup is supposed to taste like, but just know...they use a very pungent cheese on the top, so if the smell hits you when you walk in the door...that's what it is.
Duck cassoulet--stand out dish in my opinion. Flavorful and rich. For those of you who don't know a cassoulet is like French white bean chili with poultry and something fatty like sausage or porcetta 
Beef bourguignon--didn't try, by my dining companion said it was very good, and cleaned his plate!
Dessert: Souffle glace & chocolate mousse both excellent ways to finish off the meal. One refreshing and light and the other rich and creamy.

Overall I'd say try Le Central for a taste of French food. (Nothing would compare to being in Paris...so I don't know why some reviewers bother with that comparison.) It's better if you can snag a deal like happy hour or Restaurant Week.
author: Noelle L.

description:
San Francisco's finest.

Wilkes Bashford.
Herb Cain.
Willie Brown.
Us.

Not me but a former mentor and now good friend. Many years had past since seeing one another and we were long overdue to say hello.

Did so while enjoying their rich and flavorful signature roast chicken and marveling at their cassoulet that has been cooking for almost 40 years straight.

Bit confused at how my chicken was advertised as coming with broccolini (there were two small pieces) but did appreciate the greens for fries swap. Just don't expect spinach.

Probably three stars were it not for the impressive history, cassoulet and clientele. If it's a favorite of my mentor it's a favorite of mine. He has yet to steer me wrong.

Seeing Mr. Brown sitting at his favorite table might have sealed the fourth.
author: Jason B.

description: I used to come here a lot. It's very Alsatian. My favorite. The steak au poivre is AWESOME!!!!!
author: Barbara B.

description:
We came here for dinner before a show at Union Square and because it was outside of the Square, we found street parking just 2 blocks away in FiDi.  

The escargots reminded me of the ones I had in Paris, simple classic of just herb and butter leaving me enough to put on my baguette.  The cassoulet may look small but is very rich so make sure to share your entrees to balance out the richness.  For our second entree, it was the butterfish special which was a nice lighter alternative.  

The service was spotty however as it took a few minutes for the hostess to even notice us standing there as she had her back to us and was chatting with her coworkers.  I notice the same with others of the staff throughout dinner as well where they tend to congregate around the bar area talking.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
We have been meaning to try this place for years.  While the service was good, it is unfortunate to say that the feel of this place is more like a typical touristy Union Square eatery than it is the storied, authentic French bistro we were hoping it would be.

Starters of duck pate and French onion soup with baguette were quite good.  We had the steak frite, which while solid was unspectacular.  They were cooked to order at least.

Just little touches, like the paper on the tables rather than white table cloths, and the fact that none of the staff were actually French.  This is in the heart of the unofficial French district of San Francisco and right down the street from Cafe DeLa Presse and the French Consulate.... Well, where the French Consulate used to be for years before it moved.

To be honest, the food is probably better than your average Union Square tourist trap,  but at these prices, it's a bit harder to recommend.  Maybe we were expecting too much, but the ambiance was also not nearly as charming and authentically French as we were hoping.
author: Dave N.

description:
Love Le Central! Excellent food, warm and welcoming service puts this restaurant at one of my favorites in the city.  I love the old school vibe and the traditional dishes. It's perfect on a classic SF foggy day. If you're new to the area, step off the main drag and enjoy some really authentic old school SF dining. Many of the French spots nearby are a little touristy, and not as great of service. Have been there about 8 times - for dinner and for cocktails at the bar, and it's always great. 

The dinner is a little pricey, but worth it for quality food. The happy hour, however, is a great deal. Tip: go to happy hour early, and catch some of their great happy hour drinks and food at the bar.
author: Hyly K.

description:
I've been coming here for over a decade, and not once have I ever been disappointed. The food is fantastic and it won't break your wallet. I used to work off of New Montgomery, and this was a favorite spot for all of our Executives. Lunches, dinners, or even just for drinks after work - there's not a bad time to go to Le Central. They have daily specials and their bartenders always know their stuff! If you're not sure what you want to drink, just give them an idea and they'll make something to match whatever you're craving.

The space here is limited, as with most SF spots, so try to make reservations, or be prepared for a small wait on weekends. This also makes parking the pits. And keep in mind that it's close to the gates of China Town, so you might get a few odd odors by the door, along with the wandering tourists.
author: T P.

description:
I kept it simple and had the French onion soup, a chicken caesar and the Côtes du Rhône by the glass. All were very good, and the folks I was with said their Filet Mignon and Seabass were both good as well. I actually was going to order but skipped the scallops because I could smell our table-neighbor's from 4 feet away and they did not smell appetizing. 

The service was relatively fast, though not what I'd characterize as welcoming (they were just to the point, not unfriendly).

The price/performance is not very high. It's not exactly what I'd call a *fancy* French restaurant, even though Steak-Frites is $32. The restaurant overall is dated, and the food not great enough to demand those prices.
author: Chris T.

description: So, my fiancé and I just ate here and I have to say that we were nothing short of impressed by both the meal and the service. The presentation was excellent, the portions exactly as they should be for a French restaurant. We ordered the Grilled Salmon with Asparagus and the Fillet Mignon with the pomme puree (mashed potatoes). Cooked to perfection! To conclude the meal, we had the Creme Brulee that was once again, prepared to perfection that would most certainly give many restaurants in Paris a run for their money. Bon Appétit!
author: Gerald D.

description: This was probably one of the WORST dining experiences that I have ever had. We came here for my best friends birthday dinner. My partner was not feeling well and needed to go to the bathroom. I went with him to make sure he was ok. Another friend also came back a little bit after to check on him, he was fine, just sick. The bartender then took it upon himself to come back to the bathroom and very publicly yell, for the entire restaurant to hear, "What's going on? Are you two ok in there?". My friends also overheard the bartender making snide remarks about the two of us. He implied the two of us were doing something in the bathroom together. I am appalled that a restaurant would employ such a despicable human being that would treat its customers so poorly. He continued to laugh loudly about the situation. I would never recommend this restaurant to anyone. The restaurant manager seemed to approve of this behavior as all she offered to do to rectify the situation was to give us her business card and to join them at a later date. We immediately asked for our bill so we could leave. Upon paying the tab and leaving, we observed the restaurant manager and another employee eating the dinner we had ordered. It's a very unfortunate thing as the appetizers we had tasted were great but their employees ruined it. I have never had such a demeaning experience in my life and would urge you to stay far, far away.
author: Josh S.

description: This was the worst dining experience of my life. I have never been insulted and treated so poorly by staff at an establishment. The bartender was out of line and completely rude to my husband and I. I will never go back here. We didn't even stay for our entrees. Completely disgusting!
author: Danielle M.

description:
It's time to update my review of Le Central.   We like this small restaurant and have been here several times for lunch.  One of these times we must try dinner here. Not sure the menu is any different.  But the service is always consistent.  Once seated, water or beverage is offered and then you are presented with menus and a small blackboard listing the specials of the day.  I highly recommend those!

We both had Petrale sole in a lemon butter sauce with boiled potato, carrot, and broccoli on the side.  It was perfectly cooked with an egg wash and then sautéed.  At least that's how I tasted it.  There were two portions of sole so my husband and I could've easily shared this dish.  We did split a butter lettuce salad to start and that is always good with a light creamy vinaigrette dressing and a small amount of chopped egg on top.

We had excellent black coffee and skipped dessert.  We were full.  And we will  definitely be back.  One can always count on Le Central for a good meal---it rarely changes and it's nice to be able to know what to expect!
author: Mary A.

description:
Back here on a business trip after too many years... Crossed the bay for a dinner!
Service is fantastic and the cassoulet is amazing, like it has been for more than 40 years!!!
author: Renaud J.

description: Ember is the best female bartender in the Bay Area.
author: David W.

description: We went here for date night. Service was ok. Food was good. Large portions. Classic French fare but reasonably priced. Dessert is the reason this got four stars. The meals were nothing to call home about, but the dessert was spectacular. If it's a cold night and you want some French onion soup and some steak frites, this is where I would go. Don't sit in the bar, sit in the dining room, it's much nicer.
author: Liza C.

description: Went to this place because the restaurant we initially planned to go "Akiko's" next door was completely booked.  Should have known better before we even stepped in here s the place was virtually empty on a Friday evening.  The ambient is good but the food is horrible.  Just horrible. The worst "Salad Nicoise" I've ever had.  The tuna was cooked solid as a rock. The unfriendly waiter proceeded to tell me that this is the French way of cooking (vs searing it slightly).  That may have been but I am sorry, it can't be the French way to make it taste terrible.  Too much dressing on the rest of the dish.  The crab cake is OK but way too dry, making me think they took it out of the fridge and microwave it.  The only saving grace is that my friend's scallop dish is done properly, seared lightly.  She seemed to think they dumped on too much butter.  The worst thing is my stomach was upset the next morning... I would not come here again.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Oh my gosh -just checked out some of these reviews and I'm incredulous -what a fantastic place in that the staff are the most attentive -the food is fantastic and there is nothing amiss - 

This place is a "go-to" place -totally consistent - great spot whether it's a quiet meal or a celebration

Do ask what's NOT on the menu -they ALWAYS try to accommodate their guests -it's the French way of doing things!
author: Ruthie N.

description:
I had dinner on June 16th when the Cassoulet was 13,662 days old or 37.4 years old. The Cassoulet was very dense and rich. Packed with white beans, duck, pork and lamb stewed together for 37 years, you start to feel the effects after eating half of it.  After finishing the meal, food coma started to blanket me and there was a need for coffee.

Luckily I also split a fish special, breaded and baked, over vegetables in a white sauce.

I came here for a early dinner, most of the patrons were at the bar drinking, towards the end of dinner there were more patrons having dinner. Looking at the menu, the next item I would like to try is the Blood Sausage special!
author: Brandon W.

description: Only rating the drink menu and bar as I'm not eating. I stopped in for a glass of wine and was surprised by the limited offerings at this French cafe. My by the glass choice ended up being a CA Zin! Attentive bartender and it looks like the food would be good. I may have to come back for food!
author: Jim U.

description: Never a bad meal. Far too much emphasis by Yelp reviewers on who eats there, not enough on superb French bistro fare. Had cassoulet this week, perfect for cold weather. As always, my server was a gem, she always is
author: Christopher F.

description: Very nice lunch. French food that was fresh and delicious. Great service. I will return. We both had halibut special which was perfectly cooked. Ceasar was real.
author: Ann P.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up!  My friend and I came here for Dine About Town, and it was an enjoyable place for us to catch up.  

Had:
* Baguette (loooooove baguettes - I have to STOP myself from eating it all and something about the kind of butter they serve it with was *SO* good, I really tried to make myself stop, really)
* A refreshing glass of sparkling wine
* Crab cake (perfectly crispy, loved it, mmm, I would order this again in a heartbeat)
* Salmon (I try to eat fish twice a week and tonight I wanted salmon, nicely cooked, got full on the baguette so had to take it home, lovely as leftovers, mmm!)
* Crème brûlée (sweet, creamy, gone gone gone in seconds)

Nice service, great location, quaint, feels like a piece of SF history.  Glad I got to try Le Central.
author: Maile N.

description: Mediocre at best. Came her with some friends for lunch. Music was blaring and they were playing Beach Boys, Doo Wap, and Motown. All music I love, but incongruous in a French restaurant. Food was so so. I ordered the salmon and it came out luke warm. For 24.00 I would expect it to be piping hot. Bartender was great and made delicious cocktails. Food just seemed to be lacking. Always wanted to try it, and now I have.
author: Lauren K.

description:
We walked in for week diner. Not terribly authentic French. Doesn't appear to be cook to order
Steak tartare was really basic while onion tart with too much onions but taste good.
author: Claire C.

description:
The best happy hour in the city. Five dollar Bordeauxs. Ask for an ashtray in French and they might bring you one with a complimentary pack of Thai cloves. 

Oysters clams and crabs....  Good food also. 

The bartenders are wonderful, engaging and friendly.
Very small folks. Brother and sister, i think. One wears ties. The fellah loves Underberg. Tip him with underbergs and he will tell u a funny story about something Willie Brown or Don Johnson did there... His Melanie Griffith impression is spot-on. 

A simple old school french menu. Atmosphere is intimate and inviting. Winona Ryder comes here after shopping at Niemans. I asked to see her receipts. She was totally cool with that. Classy. 

Some weird Marin chitchat at bar this last time. Only drawback. We should ban them. Mr Gorbachev, bring this bridge down!

Nazdrovie! Merci duchamp. 


Old San Francisco at its best.
author: venice anon A.

description: We ordered a lovely dinner. We started with escargot that were the best we ever had. I had a quinoa and chicken salad that was sooo good and my husband had steak tartare. The service was outstanding and we had a wonderful time.
author: ilene g.

description:
I love a restaurant where the owner greets you warmly as does the wait staff like you're old friends. 

That wouldn't be enough, however, to garner the consistently great reviews and loyal customers that Le Central has and deserves unless they also served delicious, often sophisticated, bistro fare. 

They do -and they do it so well..

Today, I took my BFF for a belated birthday lunch. We'd actually planned this lunch for 8 months at her very specific request - based on my rave reviews - to celebrate her birthday at Le Central.

We grazed through the menu so she could sample their classic fare of the onion tart (so buttery and delicious), the crab cake (pure crab meat, plated on a beurre blanc sauce) and then for me, a difficult choice of what to choose for an entree. 

My friend had already decided months in advance she was having their popular chicken pommes frites (side of super-garlicky aioli, by request) and I had the filet mignon au poivre. It was the best piece of beef I'd had in years, so tender and buttery -and it was perfectly cooked (rare). Despite its generous portion, I have to admit I did eat every bite.

Frequent Le Central customer Willie Brown was having lunch there with Ron Dellums and Wilkes Bashford generously let me intrude on a talk of current movies (I overheard him saying how much he loved the movie, "The King's Speech.")

Even though he really doesn't know me, but has spotted me from time to time at Le Central, Mr. Bashford gave me a gracious good-bye and good wishes for the New Year. Le Central engenders that unpretentious and friendly atmosphere.

And the good food and service put it on my "Top 5" places to dine in the City. 

If you haven't gone there yet, put it on your New Year's resolution list.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Absolutely delicious meal. Loved the onion soup, scallops, goat cheese tarte and our Louis Latour wine.  Scott out fabulous waiter was very attentive and made excellent suggestions for wine and soup.  Service by Scott was five star and I would definitely return for another elegant meal.
author: Blue S.

description:
There is something to be said for a French Restaurant which touts that it's cassoulets have been burning for over 14,000 days!

But seriously, their cassoulet is excellent.  Decently priced and quite filling.  

This is a very traditional French Bistro, white table cloths, waitstaff in ties, a Matre'd, and simple (read elegant) cuisine.  

The salad is a kind one does not see often in bistros anymore: a cut wedge, with simple vinaigrette. 

Their steak au pouivre is incredible, as is their rack of lamb.  

All in all, a great spot in San Francisco, that needs to be patronized by all who can.
author: Devin C.

description:
The worst thing about this restaurant is choosing what to order, everything is just too good! The thing I love about this place is that is that it offers the best of what I crave in a French meal; delicious ingredients really, really well prepared that just taste like the best home cooked meal ever. 

Take their cassoulet, it tastes like comfort in a bowl and the Paté de Campagne, well, who doesn't like pork with a side of pickles? The Goat Cheese & Leek Tart Frisée, is something I could eat everyday of my life and the Grilled Wild Salmon Beurre Nantais is crazy good. I could go on and on but there are other things I love about this place. 

The ambiance is old world charming and not in a faux way. Le Central is forty years old and it lives in a brick building significantly older than that, it has a fabulous brass bar top imported from France, comfy seating and decor just funky enough to feel homey; I feel like I'm eating at a friend's house.

Our waiters have always been knowledgeable and exceptionally good at their job. I have to admit the last time my sweetheart and I ate here he had just one too many glasses of the delicious wine we ordered and he was just a tad boisterous. Our waiter was not thrilled but handled it like a pro and a lovely dry wit. 

This really feels like an authentic French bistro experience in the heart of San Francisco. I just wish I lived closer and could eat here every week!
author: Addison M.

description:
We spent the past Valentine's Day here. It was good!

It took longer than we thought to get there so I called them to let them know we would be late for our reservation. They appreciated the call they said. A half hour later, we walked in and they accommodated us with no problem. Very nice of them.

The space is very tight. However, it seemed to work out ok. You get to know fellow diners and what they are having.

It was a pre fixed menu for the evening. Having been to France the year before we were eager to try the American version of the foods we loved. 

The Escargots de Bourgogne was succulent. I could not stop dipping my baguette into the left over sauce of garlic, herbs and butter. 

The French onion soup was exactly what we had hoped for with the abundance of gruyere cheese and savory broth.

We had the Filet Mignon au Poivre. It was the best we both have ever tasted. Simply perfection melting in your mouth. I had a Sea Bass I believe, but I kept eating from my husband's plate instead. YUM!

Our experience with the Crème Brulee was not as good. We found it to have an egg-like consistency rather than a smooth texture.

The wait staff was helpful and courteous. I think we were expecting the waiter to clean the crumbs from the table with a crumb sweeper. But only because we experienced that before in other French restaurants

I must give applause to our waiter (which I forgot his name, blonde gentleman).

We told him we were on our way to the symphony and he advised us on a shortcut to get us there on time. 

We made it! Thank you Sir. :)

And thank you all for a lovely Valentine evening for my husband and I.
Cheers!
author: Brenda S.

description:
The first time I went, I would have given the place 5 stars. The roasted beet salad was to die for. I would have returned just for that! The crab cakes were melt in your mouth. The second time I went, the beet salad was not as I had remembered, it was not as fresh. Perhaps beets were out of season? They serve a very delicious local butter with their bread. It's the small things! I could have just eaten it. I was glad to see that this did not change. 

Will I return. Oui, bien sur!
author: Kae J.

description:
The Setting:  Dinner with a coworker, Tuesday night 8pml, had a reservation, seated immediately.

Food: 4 stars
Service: 2.5 stars
And ditto Q.L's post about the host being a bit awkward...

The GOOD:
1.  Escargot - I'm kind of a sucker for Escargot, but this was quite good.  The snails were cooked perfectly and the butter sauce with the bread was wonderful.
2.  Cassoulet - wow.  Get this.  We both loved it!  Meat and White beans and sauce were all amazing.
3.  Creme Brulee - I've had some bad creme brulee and it seems easy to mess up, but this was well executed.

The OK:
1.  Grilled Salmon - While good, this was completely overshadowed by the Cassoulet and Escargot.
2.  Service - While kind and well meaning, the staff was less attentive than I would have expected at a restaurant with the upscale atmosphere.  We had to ask for water and had to ask for a refill.  And had to ask for the bill twice.

The BAD:  nothing

The Bottom Line - Very good food and atmosphere with fairly mediocre service.  But for the price point and food quality ($60/person got us an appetizer, two entrees, a dessert, and a half-bottle of wine) this place is worth visiting, especially with it being worth 1,000 points on OpenTable (equivalent of $10 credit).
author: Kevin S.

description: Amazing onion soup and escargos. My favorites! What a treat to go here. Enjoyed every bite.
author: Betsy R.

description: Nice upscale restaurant. Had the Onion Tart (it was lunch) and it was good. Next time I will get the long-time-cooking stew.
author: Brian S.

description: Unlike the industrial-chic look that has permeated most of San Francisco's newest dining establishments, this restaurant stays true to it's roots and transports you to a french bistro. Ok they do have an exposed brick wall but it is offset by their great bar and white table clothes - this isn't manufactured authenticity, it IS authenticity. I love going to this place because people are refreshingly open to having a conversation with you instead of just looking at their iPhones. The food is classic french - no noveau french, not french infused - classic french. Try their steak tartare - it's some of the best in the city because they use better cuts of meat than most of the other restaurants. If you are low-carb you can always get it with endive instead of toast. Best part of this place is sitting at the bar - if you are fortunate for Kirsten to be working that evening she will entertain you until you realize you were supposed to go home 3 hours ago. Who knows you might also run into Willy Brown playing liars dice there if you are lucky. Definitely a place to come to and experience because you get that local feel of a restaurant that knows who it is.
author: Megan P.

description:
Le Central has one of the best roasted chicken with pomme frites in the city!! That is my favorite dish. The salads and soups are good too (fresh ingredients and simple preparations).

The place has an old time atmosphere, which I like. I think it's amusing how they use a large board of "specials" that they put on your table. It's crowded during lunch time, but dinner is usually more pleasant.

And yes, this place is expensive for a bistro. Service is not perfect. But I like to drop by when I crave their roasted chicken and pomme frites (always perfectly prepared - tender chicken with au jus, toasted skin, and crispy golden fries). Very yummy!!
author: Luis C.

description:
Went here again last evening. Yum yum yum yum.  I had the special.  It was brisket with a horseradish sauce, potatoes and spinach.  It was PERFECTLY done brisket and it exceeded my expectations.  I had the onion tart as well- My dining partner had the duck rillettes with aspic yum yum yum yum and the escargot and the cassoulet- all SUPER great.  He did not really eat all of it himself, for I, of course ate some too.  Everything was delicious!!!

I love this place, can't you tell?  It is a down and dirty French restaurant.  The cassoulet has been on the stove for 13,000 some plus days and a few months thus far.  The service is so nice and unpretentious, and it is not over priced.  We got to sit at a table by the window and talk and enjoy ourselves for a few hours.  I hope this place stays open forever!
author: Lisa M.

description:
i don't know why we decided to come here for New Year's Eve dinner but so glad that we did.  We probably passed by this place a gazillion times in Union Square without ever noticing it! This was one of the only restaurants that had a reservation for 8pm available for a table of 7 so off we went.  

Upon entering, the place is really charming. In addition to the NYE decor, I like the exposed brick wall, the two dining rooms separated by the bar, and the cozy bistro feeling of the restaurant (it's the oldest French bistro in the city!). Our hostess was really friendly and seated us to our table even though only 1/3 of our party was there. Our waiter was the no nonsense efficient but nice kind of guys-kinda reminded us of Chris Farley.

Reviews from the peanut gallery:

*Cassoulet-pretty good, heavy stew if you are in the mood
*Rack of lamb-good and cooked perfectly
*Filet Mignon Au Poivre-delicious and cooked a perfect medium!
*Pomme Frittes-fresh of the fryer..yum!
*scallop entree-yummo
*Cappucinos-just the way I like it and the perfect way to end the meal.

I was really worried that this place would be a disappointment but I think everyone enjoyed their meal (whew). The portions are also perfect, not too big, not too small, just right!
author: Betty C.

description:
Random night in union square brought me here for dinner. Looked up on yelp, and only 1 friend reviewed this place...... Cher, selena, where u guys at? Could be a bad sign.

Something about the host seemed off. But anyways the customer service here lacks slightly compared to other French restaurants in sf. Food wise here's the low down.
