Clams - a little too much garlic but had a nice sharp kick to it. Mustve been chili peppers. But the broth was so good I had more bread to go with it.

Pork chop - a little dry but that's ok. Well seasoned. The sides that came with it was really well done. The scalloped potatoes had a creaminess to them while still having a nice bite to it. The beets and raspberry sauce added a sweet and sour taste to the dish. So much contrast of textures and flavors going on in this dish.

Not bad but could be better.
author: Q L.

description:
3.5 stars

We were headed to try Gitane but they are not opened yet.  So why not try Le Central?  It's been around for a long time...

We only wanted apps and wine so we sat at the bar.  The bartender, Heather, was very friendly and attentive to all her customers.  We sat at the inner corner and just admired the space and its history.  A lively regular came in and started a conversation with us...and then another regular came later and she was very friendly.   We can see this as a Cheers to many and an enjoyable spot to enjoy a drink or two to release a day or week's of stress...

We had:
a glass of Bordeaux - $10.50
a glass of Cabernet - $11.50
a dozen of oysters - $24 - ok, not chilled enough
steak tartare - $15.50 - absolutely DELICIOUS!

It is not easy to find restaurants serving steak tartare, harder yet to find a good one...we will happily return just to have the steak tartare, YUM!
author: Gloria H.

description:
Escargot and pate was as good as in France! Cassoulet was amazing and gluten free (win!). 
Pretty small place and had to overhear some very strange conversations, but the meal made it worthwhile.
author: Gramma L.

description:
Absolue fantastique !!

This is the ideal spot to celebrate Bastille Day (July 14th). It's all about traditional, heavy country style French cuisine. (Not the modern light fair.) It's frequented by old money personalities dressed to impress. I'm told Willie Brown has a permanent table at the entrance of the restaurant. 

We made last minute dinner reservations through OpenTable in honor of Bastille Day. The moment I walked in from the streets of downtown San Francisco, I was transformed to Aix en Provence, France. Once we arrived, they greeted us and seated us immediately. Everyone was dressed in French berets and patriotic neckties. The two small dining rooms and bar area were serenaded by a talented accordion player with traditional French tunes. At times, the musician would hum along with his music and customers hummed or sang along as well.

This is a small restaurant with lots of tables close to each other so we made new friends with revelers on both sides of us. Every time someone got up, the servers were right there to shift the table to help you in and out. It felt just like a packed family dinner table. The entire dining room felt like someone's home. Great service throughout our dinner. 

Instead of the regular dinner menu, a special Bastille Day menu was offered. It included several of their popular dishes. We couldn't resist the aromas coming from the kitchen.

Appetizers:
French Onion Soup - hmmm....skip next time.
Escargots - Great!

Entree:
Cassoulet - Delicious!  (if you've never had it, it has white beans, sausage and duck served in a little iron pot cassoulet.)
Beef Bourguignon - Flavorful!

Dessert:
Lemon Souffle - Light and tart! Absolute must order!

A wonderful neighborhood gem right down the street from the French Consulate. It's a must visit if you live in SF or just visiting. It's a small and very popular restaurant so reservations are highly recommended.
author: Christine T.

description: I love this place and have been coming here for a few years now. My favorite dish is the cassoulet. The escargot and celery remoulade are amazing appetizers. The desserts are quite good. Right now you can get the best deal in the city for great french food -- a $40 prixe fixe which includes an appetizer, an entree, a dessert AND a glass of wine!
author: Ish H.

description:
Extremely disappointing. I wish I had checked Yelp prior to eating there because I notice that they have 3.5 stars, and after my experience I find that many stars to be very generous. We were 3 for dinner. Entered the restaurant and were seated immediately because it's wednesday and not too many people were out having dinner. After being seated one of my friends went to the bathroom. In that time the remaining diners ordered cocktails. When my friend returned from the restroom he ordered the same drink I had, a dirty martini. My drink came within moments of the second martini being ordered, but sadly his never arrived. After 10 minutes my friend asked the waiter, who finally acknowledged us, that the drink had never arrived. We could see the server asking the bartender only to learn that the server was not the only one to forget the beverage, but the bartender did as well. At that point my fellow diner told the sever to forget the drink. What was the point since it looked like it would take forever. I guess if we had followed a another tables approach and gotten up from our seats to inform the waiter of the need for a beverage we would have received our order.

Food. Well after the drink incident we decided to cut our orders short. No starters, just 1 dish per person plus a side of fries. I ordered the lamb chops medium rare. It was an extravagant dish and quite costly, but it was a special occasion. When they arrived I started to cut into dry overcooked meat. Instead of the juicy medium rare they were more medium to medium well. Not a good sign. Lamb is not a forgiving protein. I took a couple of bites, but realized that majority of the meat was tough and not worth the effort to chew. Upon realizing this the server offered to get me something else, but considering what my fellow diners were eating I didn't want to hold up the group by waiting another 15-20 minutes for a new entree. 

When the check arrived I thought to myself this is absolutely ridiculous to pay $60.36 for a meal that was neither enjoyable nor filling. I hope the servers and kitchen staff appreciated eating all the meat that was left on my plate. I should not have to pay for the staff meal and definitely learned my lesson. San Francisco restaurants can care less about their diners. They just think we're going to go quietly after bad service and terrible food. I hope others see this review and think twice before wasting their time and money.

Spend a little extra to teach your staff proper techniques for the dining room as well as the execution of your menu.
author: S P.

description: What a great place. Our bartender, Kierstan, is an absolute delight. Great drinks and conversation and a fantastic happy hour.
author: Steve K.

description: I really loved the food and I had a really great experience.Charlie was really nice My daughter even got to see a special show.
author: MARY GRAY S.

description:
Delicious, classy, service-oriented, and all-around great. Choosing what to eat was difficult, and I was glad the menu wasn't any longer; it was particularly fun to have the daily specials on a small chalkboard that was delivered to the table.The cassoulet was excellent, though I'll admit some might find it just a touch salty. My sea scallops were exquisite - tender and just barely opaque all the way through. The service was attentive and unobtrusive throughout, charming but nearly invisible. The brick walls, patterned floor, and general decor all reminded me strongly of my time in France

What put it over the top for me, though, was the end of the meal. Without a word, the waiter brought out a plate of their tiramisu with "Happy Birthday!" written lavishly in chocolate drizzle on a base of sweet cream for my companion. Two glasses of dessert wine accompanied dessert and made for a perfect denoument. 

Tres bon noir - merci!
author: Bill B.

description: Been in business 40 years now and no wonder, a true French restaurant in the middle of downtown San Francisco 1/2 a block away from the gates of China Town on Bush.   The warm goat cheese salad is terrific and the prawn risotto is the ONLY thing I order because it is so good.    Been here for dinner probably 30+ times and have great memories of entertaining co-workers and friends and many quiet nights alone...
author: John P.

description: It was ok. Went for brunch and all 4 people in my party were unimpressed. For the money and nice atmosphere I expected more. Wouldn't go back.
author: Scott C.

description: The BEST Escargots de Bourgogne and Poached Salmon in town! Le Central can sometimes be mistaken as a private club for San Franciscans. The service is extremely attentive and the  employees remember the names of the regulars. I wish to express my gratitude to Paul, Charlie, Eric, Toni, Louie, Scotty, Jimmy, Johnny, et al. Congratulations.
author: S R.

description: Good food. Good service. One of the best filet mignon's in the city; has a black peppercorn sauce that's fantastic. Definitely in the heart of the tourist-y area of SF, but worth a visit. Also, they are on open table, which I am a fan of.
author: Ryan P.

description:
Mixed feelings about this place. I ordered the Escargot to start and had the rack of lamb and cremebule for dessert. 
Escargot was great well done to that and i got an extra one of the hole had 2 of them score for me!
rack of lamb was also great it was seasoned very well. it came with 8 ribs and it was hard to finish but i did anyways since i didn't want it to go to waste :) 
the creme bule was decent. seeing so many reviews for this i decided to give it a try and it was only alright. the biggest thing i ddin't like about it was the temperature that it was served. the bottom of the creme bule was cold like it had been in the refrigerator while the top was warm since they had just caramelized the sugar on top. so it wasn't very enjoyable. 

the setting is also very crowded. even though the place was not at all. we were there at 530 on a saturday night we tried to make reservations later but they said it was all booked. but still saw a bunch of empty tables when we left around 7. the tables are set really close to one another so you can easily over here what the next table was talking about (i did over hear a great story). We were seated parallel to the bar. to sit down you have to pull the table out so that there is room to squeeze by and also when you have to get out to go to the bathroom it was a big hassle. also i sat on the outside not against the wall and my chair was being hit all the time and that was with no one sitting at the bar stool behind me i can only imagine what it would be like if someone was sitting behind me at the bar.  The service was attentive and nice but the setting of this little restaurant trying to pack in as many tables as they possibly could really need
author: Steven N.

description:
This place is a BIG JOKE.   

For many, many years, I would pass this restaurant and have always been intrigued by tthis "French" restaurant that supposedly had a lot of history.  Finally, I found time to stop by and have lunch here last Friday.  After reading so many positive reviews, I was excited to finally try Le Central!  With that in mind, my expectations were quite high...

What a surprise!  I t hought this was a French restaurant...but I think I actually walked into a Chinese restaurant.  From the host/owner(?)/manager(?), to the waiter, to the bus boy to the cook!!!, they were all Chinese!  The service I received was also comparable to a dimsum experience -- harried.  They spoke Chinese too! (IN A FRENCH RESTAURANT!!!???)

I ordered the French Onion Soup - which was bland and very ordinary ($9)

For entree, I had the Sea Bass special of the day - supposedly fillet -- but had 4 big bones ($28).  This too was very ordinary, bland and dry.

Lemon Souffle for dessert that didn't do anything for me ($11).  This is comparable to something you can order from Denny's.

Diet coke was served in a 6 inch tall, very narrow glass, full of ice.  I probably had 2 good, long sips from my straw...and like magic, it was all gone. ($3.50)  I asked for a refill and I don't know what I was thinking.  I guess I expected a bottomless drink.  Until I got my bill and I got charged $7 for my Diet Coke.  I asked tthe waitress if this was perhaps a mistake and she said it wasn't a mistake.  I told her I only got 2 good sips from the first glass because it was basically 80% ice.  But she just shrugged and said "oh  no, that's the way we do it.".

One of the reviews commented on the staff brown-nosing the host/owner/manager; SO TRUE!!!  The staff not once failed to whisper something to host/owner/manager everytime they passed him.  

The place was also filthy.  It didn't help that I sat right in front of the kitchen.

1 and 2 star reviews are so so true.  This place is a BIG TIME WANNABE.

Probably once upon a time this place was a must-go.  What a complete waste of time and money.
author: Jake R.

description: A nice french-inspired bistro.  They have a fun wine program (currently featuring one of my wines, Corkscrew Luma Blanc).  A great place for tourists and locals alike.
author: Kaveh A.

description:
I just had dinner here last night to celebrate my 1.5 year anniversary with my boyfriend so I thought I'd write this review while the experience is fresh in my mind.

The first thing we both thought when we walked in was, "wow this place is French."  -- as in the decor.  We were seated right away because we had a reservation (general tip:  whenever you can, make a reservation, it will make dinning out a lot easier).  

The tables are veryyy close together (in fact, the waiter had to pull the table out for me to get to my seat.  Also it did get pretty loud during dinner, but not unbearable and understandable considering the place was packed.  It was pretty busy so we were served by just random waiters which made it a bit confusing when it came to asking for the bill at the end.

As for food, we had the crab cake for our appetizer and my bf really liked it but I found it a bit too "carb-y"?  Later he had the half chicken and said it was pretty good and I had the grilled salmon.  OMG.  Best salmon ever.  Not fishy, buttery, and soft and the sauce was amazing too.  

As for the price, I think it was a BIT overpriced for what it was, but then again it is a slightly fancier place.  This is considered a classic in SF so I recommend trying it, but I'm not sure if I'll go back (maybe just for the salmon).

If I could, I'd give this place a 3.5.
author: Vy L.

description:
I came here recently and got the prix fixe dinner for dine about town. 

First of all, I really liked the ambiance - it's very French, from the decor, to the staff, to the way the tables are pushed very closely together. 

The food: I got the french onion soup, which was good, but seasoned with too much pepper, which overwhelmed the dish and kind of killed it for me. The main course was roast chicken with veggies and mashed potatoes - this is a classic and they did a great job; I usually don't like chicken but this was delish, I could not stop eating. Finally, the chocolate mousse for dessert was solid, but its hard to screw that up. 

Overall this place was not an amazing food find, but I think its a solid neighborhood french spot. The one complaint I have is that the wine was horrible - first I asked the waiter for a recommendation, and it was a step above 2-buck-chuck quality. The second glass I decided to take a chance and was disappointed once again. For a French restaurant, I would like to see a better and more extensive wine list.
author: Tailor A.

description:
What?  I have never reviewed this?  Okaaay.
It is actually one of my least fave places.  BUT, the hubs was brought up in a polish household and his mother served him Boudin Noir.  That is blood sausage for the rest of us.  He swears that the BN here is just like what his mom iced to make.  He loves it and makes us come every time we are here.  It is served with French fries.  I have no idea what it tastes like.  Today, they has pumpkin soup on the special board and it was just perfect.
author: Cassie P.

description: I have eaten at Le Central many times over the years and it feels as comfy as my old flip flops that my wife keeps wanting me to dispose of.  I have eaten through the menu and tend to stay on the light side of all things French these days, having the simple salads (when can you wax ecstatic about endive) and the frites and the onion soup.  Hey, this makes it a treat for veg-heads, but the fish and meats are also excellent.
author: Richard B.

description: Went into this bar for the second time. I'm not sure if they changed bar tenders or just got more pretentious. Got off work from a local restaurant and came over for a drink. We were the only people not dressed in business suites. People came and left and the bar tender never gave us the time of day even after we asked for service. Extremely disappointed in the service here. Servers judge by the cover. Don't bother going if your not wearing a business attire.
author: k l.

description:
I love this place. Old school SF style. The service is always great, yeah a little surly but then again that was old school. Don't expect your ass to be kissed but know what you want, order it and get on with it.
Last night had one of the best pieces of fish in an encrusted Sea Bass. The cassoulet was great as always. Blood sausage is amazing. The short rib special fell off the bone. Places like this are dying out in favor of Nuevo cuisine and cement and steel decor. Don't get me wrong, I like new styles but you have to appreciate a place like this and be super glad it exists. Oh, and their Manhattans are amazing.
author: Dennis K.

description:
Have I lived in San Francisco a long time?  
Yes.  
Have I walked by this place a million times?  
Yes.  
Am I kind of embarrassed that I never ate at this San Francisco institution until this past weekend?
Yes (she says with her head hanging in shame).

When we stepped inside, it immediately felt like we were transported to a cute little Paris restaurant...minus snooty waiters and dogs at the tables.   It was a relaxed atmosphere and just felt comfortable.  If you go, try to get the table for four near the window.  It's fun to look out at the street or be near the open window on a warm evening (like we were).

I loved some of the little touches, like bringing the specials of the day on a board that they propped up on a tiny easel so we could all see it.  We also liked the way they served our martinis, too.  They served them in small martini glasses with only part of the martini in the glass.  The remainder came tiny little carafes sitting on ice in small buckets to keep them cold.  So cool.

Onto the food!  The menu is classic French bistro food and we enjoyed everything that we had.  We decided to start with three appetizers and rotate them between the three of us:  beet salad (I'm a huge fan of beets and there were a ton of them), asparagus vinaigrette (special of the day), and prosciutto with cantaloupe.  All were light and nice starts to the meal.

For entrees we all chose something different.  I usually don't order chicken at restaurants, but for some reason it was calling out to me and I had the roast chicken with fries.  It was so moist and had lots of flavor.  My other friends chose the cassoulet and the halibut special and enjoyed both of them.  

The waitress was stretched thin as she was the only waitstaff there that night (not sure why because it was a Saturday night...maybe someone was sick), but I thought she did a great job.  She was friendly and we didn't feel like our service suffered at all.  We didn't have dessert, but we wouldn't have had time anyway as we needed to make a 7PM show.

The food isn't inventive or anything, but one doesn't go there for that.  It's just good food in a cozy atmosphere and you can carry on a good conversation with friends.  I'll visit again and would recommend it to my friends.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
Nina and I met our friend Lynn here for lunch today.  She had a hair appointment next door and made a reservation on OpenTable.  Nina and I took BART in and walked up from the Montgomery Street station, just a few blocks.  It had been rainy this morning but the sun smiled on us.  BART went smoothly, there was almost no rain and we were on the early side for our 12:30 reservation.  We were welcomed, seated and given menus.  Lynn arrived at 12:30.  We had almost decided what we were going to have when the waitress realized we had not been shown the specials board.  She did and when Nina and I saw chicken livers that blew away anything else we had thought to order.  Lynn stuck w/ the roasted half chicken and frîtes she had decided on.  We were given a basket w/ sliced baguette and butter.  Lynn and I each had a glass of Vouvray, which was bit sweeter than either of us had expected, but was tasty and not too sweet.

The chicken livers, which were cooked w/ Calvados and cream and served over pasta, were easily among the best we have had.  Every bite was a pleasure.  Lynn's chicken and frîtes were accompanied by sauteed spinach.  The portion was generous enough that she took some home.  We finished off w/ coffee and tea.  Service was smooth, attentive and unobtrusive and the restaurant was gloriously old school w/ dark woods, wooden floors, tables and booths.  A large wood bar fills one side of the room where you enter.  There is a single bathroom for women and one for men.  The bathroom floors are of small white hexagonal tile w/ black grout and the art on the wall of the ladies' room is charmingly French, a combination of vintage photographs, drawings and such.  As you might expect, the bathroom was spotlessly clean.  Le Central is a place I would return to.  Lunch was delicious and we enjoyed meeting in such an iconic yet unpretentious San Francisco place.
author: Toni M.

description: This place is WAY overpriced for the less than mediocre food. I ordered a Caesar Salad: It took 25 minutes and I could have made a better one myself. There was literally nothing to it. It has a cool ambiance but the food isn't good.
author: E L.

description:
My coworker and I came to try the Cassoulet, which was 13,556 days old. The restaurant was very empty at 11:30, so if you want to go for lunch, go early. The dining area did have a strange smell - more like pine-sol. The fresh flowers on the table were lovely.

The service was ok. Our server did not offer any descriptions of the specials. In fact, no specials were mentioned, but a little chalk board was hung on the wall near us so we could read them for ourselves. After our order was placed, the chalk board was taken away. I noticed an insect on the sleeve of our waiter, mentioned it to him, and he was very appreciative of my notification.

The food was ok. We ordered the endive salad, cassoulet, and the Apple Tarte Tatin. The endive salad did have a nice dressing. The cassoulet was served in a very cute, Le Cruset mini-cocotte. The Tarte Tatin, was not sweet and bits of the apple core were in the apples. It kind of had a strange flavor, as I expected some apple taste and maybe a hint of caramel, but it didn't taste like that at all. It was served cold with whipped cream and caramel sauce.

As the restaurant filled during lunch time, it was as if a play had begun and the characters began to fill the stage. You can tell there are a lot of characters that dine a Le Central on a regular basis.

All in all, I'm glad we went for the experience, but I'm not sure if I would come back again. 

Here is my blog entry with photos:

http://madeitlikeamy.wordpress.com/2012/03/14/le-central-and-the-13556-day-old-cassoulet/
author: Amy V.

description: Want an old school SF lunch? This is the place. Food is great, scene is awesome and service is top notch. All that will cost you what it should cost you, which isn't cheap.
author: Conor B.

description: I love Le Central -- it's a fabulous country french place! I go here for lunch whenever I'm in town and always order the celery remoulade (Classic!) and cassoulet! So if you're a fan of classic french country -- you must go here; there's not many places where you find Cassoulet that been cooking like it should be!
author: Ana M.

description: Took a date here Friday night and could have had better service.  10 STARS!!!  They were super attentive and made us feel like family.  Definitely coming back!!
author: Alex G.

description:
I love old timey places like Le Central, where everything seems to have frozen in a bygone era. On a particularly melancholy Thursday, I stopped in, by myself, for lunch. Discovering Le Central was completely unexpected-- I stumbled out from a hair appointment at Elevation next door-- and totally welcome. 

I was in a terribly nostalgic mood and the small, dark European interior was inviting. I sat down with no wait around 1pm. Service was efficient, well timed, gave me sufficient space to ruminate over the tunes of Louis Armstrong. The waitress didn't bother handing me a wine list or dessert list, which was sort of surprising; usually they fall all over themselves to push a glass of cabernet or a slice of tiramisu on you. The crowd was 50+, white crust, lots of regulars. 

Lunch for one, about $50 (crab cake, grilled salmon, cappuccino, sparkling lemonade). Crab cake is generously sized, grilled salmon was rich, but not dazzling. Prices are reasonable for French bistro fare. The ambiance is not for everyone-- bring your own moody film noir attitude.
author: Alyce H.

description:
We walked in looking for Happy Hour, were seated at a table, ordered drinks and then were advised HH was only at the bar.  When we wanted a seat at both, they were disgusted.  So we had our wine, onion soup - bland and boring, and cassoulet, which the board outside noted the cassoulet had been cooking for days and days and days, but the flavor was also bland and boring.  Not worth ordering.  Could have used more fat!  HA!  
Old financial district vibe.  Several regulars in suits.  Tiny, classic space.
author: Monica S.

description: Cute French restaurant right on the line of Union Square and Chinatown.  The french onion soup was actually the best that I've had at a French restaurant in recent memory, and the fries were crisp and delicious.  I also liked that it wasn't too crazy packed so it was a comfortable dining experience all around.
author: Mel G.

description: Above average cuisine, good wine list if short, nice decor, and just average service.  It gives the impression of a place in dire need of fresh capital for remodeling.  There is no question that the chef is capable.  But the atmosphere feels like the late 1970's, and the staff while friendly are clearly not the creme de la creme in San Francisco.  I can safely say the crab cakes are large and excellent.  And the Sea Bass entree was very delicious.  I added a bottle of Pouilly Fuisse and came away quite delighted.   But please do this historic place some justice and make a few strategic upgrades.
author: Kurt L.

description: One can do better, I have been here several times and have been underwhelmed each visit. The maître d' (owner?) often seems overwhelmed and crabby. The restaurant is typically crowded with tourists  and the food is mediocre.
author: Tom J.

description: The Goat cheese Tarte was excellent. Enjoyed the Cassoulet. Can't go wrong with the Frites.
author: Mike V.

description: We have had some good meals there before .We went for lunch and sat at the bar .We were given menus but told by the barman that he would get to us when he finished his game of dice .He was gambling with a customer .They then started playing by banging down the dice cup .It was loud and there was no way we were going to enjoy a meal .So we left ,he did offer us a table but you could hear the noise of the dice every where .Very strange .
author: mark B.

description:
This place has a long, storied history. We had eaten here about 7-8 years ago and thought it was okay, but not worth the hype. We tried it again last night and came to the same conclusion: okay, but nothing remarkable. 

The food was actually very good (French onion soup and their "legendary" cassoulet for me and roasted chicken for my wife). Rather than listing the winery for each wine that they sold by-the-glass, the wine list showed only the varietal (pinot noir, merlot, etc.)...but not the name of the winery who produced it. So unless you asked, you had no idea whether you were getting 2-Buck-Chuck or something far better.

The servers and hosts were all very nice, but lacked the finesse and care that you'd expect. There wasn't a lot of down-time between courses -- it felt a little rushed. It was service with a smile -- nothing more, nothing less. Pretty much "I'm here to take your order and bring you your food." 

Moreover, one of the owners (or by all the fuss, we assumed he was the owner) was dining that night near where we sat and during the early part of our meal, he kept pacing throughout the dining room and was talking on his cell phone as he determinedly strode back and forth between the kitchen, his table and the hostess desk. 

Once his wife arrived, a continuous stream of brown-nosers from the wait staff loitered by his table in the corner, which was just a few tables from where we were sitting. It made for a rather uncomfortable dining experience, as we felt a bit like interlopers rather than welcomed guests.

So I'd give the food 3-4 stars (nothing to complain about, but not remarkable enough for the food alone to bring me back again). I'd give the service 2+ stars..."serviceable" or "pedestrian" are words that come to mind.

If you're looking for a decent meal and not a memorable dining experience, it's fine. It was our anniversary, though, and we were expecting more than just a decent meal. Oh well, as they say in France: C'est la vie...
author: Rod H.

description: Came here for lunch with a coworker the other day. He had been here many times but this was my first. The banquette tables are FAR too crowded, so we opted for the bar and glad we did. The bartender was gracious and suggested a vin ordinaire white Burgundy that was surprisingly wonderful and inexpensive. Upon my friend's recommendation, we each had the half chicken with frites. The chicken was very good - not the best I'd ever had but certainly good. The frites were perfect as was the service. The ambiance of this bistro is captivating and reminiscent of Paris. It has a "we have been here a long time" feel to it and its longevity clearly is deserved. It also appears to be a time-honored hangout for many movers and shakers in SF. All-in-all a really fine lunch and fun place to hang.
author: Kevin M.

description: Had dinner at 8 pm on a Friday night, the restaurant was dead.  The pate was good, especially with the dijon mustard.  My wife's cassoulet was very good.  I had the rack of lamb which was cooked perfectly but didn't have that much flavour.  The creme brulee was good but too liquidy.
author: David F.

description:
This is one of the 'classic' SF restaurants that is a 'must' to experience.  It is the oldest French Bistro in SF and apparently a former mayor of SF would eat lunch there every day. 
It is unpretentious, warm and welcoming. 
I accidentally found this restaurant one day when I 'missed' the official 'lunch hour' (it was 3:00pm) and while all restaurants seemed to be closed, they were open for lunch through to dinner - they do not close!  
Their food would be described as classic French food (meaning good sauces, but not too heavy and not sauces with  'everything'!), and you can tell by their steady, reliable, older, loyal crowd that they have earned loyalties through their consistent great service, food and atmosphere.
They have a wonderful - high end wine selection at very 'reasonable' prices - which is always a refreshing find!
I highly recommend at least ONE visit to this great establishment!
author: MeeSun B.

description:
Dined here alone while on a business trip to the US.

The food was acceptable, although not unique or fantastic.  Service was strange -- a bad blend of American casualness and European detatchment.

No prix fixe menu, had to ask for a wine list, paper tableclothes, etc.  French only in name.
author: Stephen B.

description: Came here with coworkers for holiday luncheon. My meal was paid for.. so maybe I'll be grading them on a curve LOL. I liked this place. Really nice French cute vibe. Food was good. I had the special which was lobster and scallops in what I would call a pot pie LOL. It was delicious with big chunks of lobster and scallops. Also had butter lettuce salad which was good. Didn't drink or eat any dessert but will definitely come back on my own with a friend or two. A good place to take out of town guests I think.
author: Vol T.

description:
As the oldest french bistro/cafe in the city, this place has so much potential.  But, unfortunately it falls way short of what it could be.  My husband and I stopped by for dinner recently and ordered two glasses of Bordeaux, the chicken dinner, and goat cheese/leek tart.  The wine tasted cheap and was undrinkable, and we had to send it back.  Dinner arrived much too quickly and was luke warm and totally boring and bland.  The 1/2 chicken plate was dominated by french fries (and I'd be surprised if that was actually 1/2 chicken). And the pear served with the tart was right out of a can. 

To the owner of Le Central - there are plenty of people who would embrace the old school french bistro. Update quality of your food, your wine and maybe hire a french server or two and you may just have a winner.
author: Sharon R.

description:
We visited Le Central for the DIne About Town 2012 prix fixe special 

First impressions: The DAT menu was varied and offered picks from some of the restaurant's most popular dishes (cassoulet, roast chicken, onion soup, etc). The ambiance was cute, although the lighting seemed strangely institutional - that bright yet dim lighting of public school, if you know what I mean. Our waiter was grumpy but attentive. There is, however, a strange smell to the place that I notice has been commented on in other reviews.

- Onion soup: OK but very oily (yes, more oily than this dish usually is). Surprised to see so much love for this in other reviews - maybe it was an off night for the onion soup?
- Cassoulet: truly delicious, but I could only eat 1/4 of the dish before I started to feel ill. I'm a big eater, but this dish was just far too rich for me - and with the oily appetizer, it was just overwhelming. I highly recommend sharing this and starting with a salad instead!
- Creme Brulee: I had a few delicious bites but felt too sick from the rest of the meal to eat much. Too bad, since it was very good. 
-Bread: I expect really delicious bread at a French bistro, and this was very mediocre.

Overall, not a bad experience, but we probably would have felt disappointed about the food had we not been paying the discounted DAT prix fixe. Be careful about the richness/fattiness of the food and save room for dessert!
author: Orla Rose B.

description: I've been here twice.  First time was for Dine About Town and the food was okay.  Second time was last week and the food was great!  We got the escargots as an appetizer and there were delish!  One of my friends doesn't even like escargots, but she could stop dipping the bread into the garlic parsley butter sauce.  It was buttery goodness!  We got the steak and scallops as well.  The steak was cooked perfectly and the scallops just melted in your mouth!  I believe this is one of the oldest French bistros in SF so if you love French food you have to check this place out!
author: Elena N.

description:
A classic San Francisco French Bistro with the waiters who have been there forever to prove it.  It bleeds tourist to locals, from Willie Brown in a fedora to folks wearing a fanny pack and I love SF sweatshirt- its all good here.

The wine list is basic, one - okay two good reds and a few nice white burgundies nothing to write home about.  The food is fine, no stand outs, French classics like roast chicken to San Francisco favorites like Petrale Sole in beurre blanc sauce are all good.

The one dish I would stay away from is the smoked trout - its so smoked and dried out it might as well be trout jerky.    

So go, you might see the Mayor at his table by the window reminiscing of Herb Caen days.
author: G R.

description:
Four stars for the food and two stars for service!

I went there with four other friends to try out their food for dine about town. I ordered the goat cheese salad, beef bourguignon, and the berry crumble. All the dishes I ordered were pretty delicious. However, the service was unacceptable. Since we had five people in the group, one of my friends was facing an empty seat. The waiter opened a bottle of wine for the two customers sitting next to us at the empty seat. He didn't even speak to my friend before doing that, but just pretended my friend was not existed. AND, there was a completely empty table literally two steps away from our table. I will NOT re-visit due to the poor customer service.
author: Sara Z.

description:
Visited for dine about town, 34.95 priced fixed 3 course.  The restaurant was good, not great.

App
French Onion Soup - rich broth nice presentation.  Great.
Crab Cake - real winner of the night.  awesome.

Entrees
Ribeye with fries - OK, salty, low quality meat.  Served with tasteless spinach.
Le Cassolet - House specialty, rustic, pretty tasty rich dish.

Dessert
Creme Caramel - Flan like substance with sticky sweet topping.  A bit sloppy but OK.
Chocolate Mousse - Pretty awesome.  Fantastic texture for a mousse which is why I normally don't like them.  Plesant suprise.

Service was acceptable.  Normally too pricy for what it is, but decent value in dine about town.
author: Chris F.

description:
So I somehow ended up here on vday which is another long story but i suppose i'll keep that one to myself.

the menu wasn't too impressive, especially for vday. where are the desserts yo??

anyway. so the bf ordered escargot for appetizer and the rack of lamb for his entree. i had the lobster bisque and the seared day boat scallops provencale.

escargot: way too much garlic, and on top of that the garlic was still pretty raw. the garlic was just waaaaay too strong and spicy.

lamb: excellent. seasoned and cooked perfectly...and i don't even like lamb!

lobster bisque... was not very bisquey. pardon me for sounding like a food snob but i could've swore that bisque is supposed to be creamy? it looked more like and tasted more like a lobster stock but oh well...

scallops provencale: i thought that this was supposed to be a thick, oily tomato-ey sauce? and although my scallops were seared, they got chewy. i think there was too much sauce poured over my scallops. also, my sauce wasn't red or tomatoey at all?? there was like.. maybe 2 pieces of sun dried tomatoes..

the side dishes that came with our entrees: spinach, sweet potatoes, cauliflower. the spinach was bland, i added a lot of salt. the sweet potatoes were also bland, how'd that happen? cauliflower was gross, and my dish came along with half of a half cooked potato. go figure.

i opted to skip out on dessert because i was actually pretty full although i didn't really finish my food. 

although i wasn't too impressed by the food, the service was great.
my extremely dirty wine glass was replaced immediately and water glass was never empty. Host was really nice, pulled out the table for me and everything. 

if you go, stay with red meat. i would've stuck with filet mignon or steak if i had known but someone told me i was going to a different restaurant so i yelp researched the wrong restaurant... but alas, i digress... I love my boyfriend, he tries. I love him dearly. 

also, everybody in the restaurant was old. either geriatric or late 50s. says something doesn't it?

and no i'm not a snobby 20 something asian hipster *rolls eyes* even though i came here.
author: Susy C.

description: "Destination" restaurant prices with lackluster, ordinary, not-at-all French food. Terrible silverware, glasses and wine glasses. Server stress with the knife on the right. A French restaurant that does not get steak frites right should close down. This one is still open.  Defrosted premise crab cakes (French??!!). Ok nothing was right about this place. Surely we can spend our money at better places in San Francisco?
author: Deepak T.

description:
I hosted a friends birthday party here and everything was just OK.. The place had an odd odor to it and the staff seemed a but confused.

Once we go going our waiter was very attentive. 
I have had much better french food in sf, and I feel it was a bit over priced for the quality of food we received. It was an over all OK experience, but I don't think I'll be going back.
author: lorrin S.

description:
Great old school French place (full of old school people). Traditional atmosphere, good service, cool Maitre'd.

Very good steaks with fries. Mine was perfectly cooked and tasty. Fresh and good butter lettuce salad. Awesome creme brulee and chocolate mousse. Great selection of wines.

I'll definitely go back!
author: David S.

description:
Nice cozy place. Both my girlfriend and I enjoyed what we had, and the service was pretty prompt (however it wasn't packed, so I can't really comment on that). 

I had the cold salmon, which was pretty good and my girlfriend had the filet mignon, which was cooked perfectly.

I wish their menu had more choices, both in food and wine by the glass. Other than that it was a good experience.
author: Michael B.

description: We were trying to get dinner before a show, and were enticed in off the street by a waiter, saying that Le Central was the longest running restaurant on the block, that the chef is French, the food is all fresh, etc. Sounds nice, but once you're seated, prepare to be underwhelmed. Service was slow and brusque. The escargot were good, but the filet steak (ordered medium rare, served well) was disappointing, and given the bill, everything should have been better...there's so many restaurants around here, not worth a visit.
author: Giles B.

description:
I experienced this amazing french restaurant last night, and I couldn't believe my taste buds!! 

I wanted to take my lady out to a fancy meal, so I had scouted out this spot and it was a real winner! Fancy, yet casual, cool vibe, i'm sure we stuck out real bad, but whatever..

The Cassoulet that this place was known for was amazing!!!!!! I've never had lamb before and this thing has Duck Confit, Lamb, Pork, and a Sausage in it, in this amazing white bean stew.... superb!

The Lady had the Goat Cheese and Leek tart, soooooooooooo goood! I  was really impressed with that one!

Everything was delicious, our waiter was very helpful, and it wasn't that expensive!

However the one thing keeping me from the 5th star... we did notice 1 single roach walking on the floor.  Not sure if this is a bad issue, but I'm just saying, I saw 1.  So.. I hope you folks read this, and take a look around!
author: Carlos C.

description:
Le Central is a very lovely restaurant with a fun ambiance and décor and which serves mostly tasty food. Only a few missteps prevent it from being great but it is solid and pleasant.

The first thing that Le Central has going for them is the design of the interior. Very lovely decorations and set-up with a mock-up of a French cafe in half of the restaurant and a more traditional dining room on the other side. Fun old-style posters, nice mirrors and booths, wooden beams, stained-glass decorations ... All of it is very lovely to look at and definitely gives it a French look without going overboard in the cliché department.

The service is friendly and our waiter was actually French which was a nice touch. I will say that we arrived early and as the evening wore on and the restaurant started to fill out, he was clearly overworked and we have to wait a LONG time for our dessert and bill. But the overall service was fine.

Now on to the food. My major critique of the menu is simple: if this is a French restaurant, then the menu should be less generic. There are handful of specifically French items on the menu - and, as we will see, they taste great - and most of what is on the menu did sound yummy to me regardless but I did go there for French food and it turned out very little was "typically French". 

We started off with onion soup, escargots and crabcakes. The onion soup - which I didn't taste because it is not my favorite - was disappointingly bland according to my dinner companion. Not bad per se but bland and a bit sweet. The cheese crust was wonderful though and it was served in a beautiful little pot which is a nice touch. 
The two other appetizers were great. The escargots were exactly as they should be - although served out of the shell which is a shame since digging them out is half the fun. The garlic sauce was delicious and they were cooked perfectly. Soft without a hint of chewiness which is wonderful. Not out of this world because to this French eater, well, that's a common French dish but very very good. 
The crabcakes on the other hand were absolutely to die for. Perfectly cooked - moist inside, crispy without being hard on the outside. The taste was crabby without being overwhelming with a nice touch of red pepper and the butter sauce was divine. We scooped it up with bread for sure!
Talking about the bread, I was a bit surprised at how unremarkable it was. It was not bad per se but definitely needed to be better-quality at a French restaurant (crispier on the outside for a start).

The entrees were very very good. The cassoulet, first and foremost, is what this place is known for and now I see why. It was just Heaven. Both because it was authentic and "as it should be" and because it tasted unbelievable on its own right. Soft and melting in the mouth without being mushy. The wonderful meats all combined together for such a luscious experience. Absolutely recommended.
As for those Yelpers who complain the "Casoulet" was too rich, my question is: did they even know what a cassoulet is? That is the way it is SUPPOSED to be. Don't knock a restaurant for making the dish exactly like it should be cooked. They are welcome to dislike cassoulet but it is their mistake for ordering it, not to the restaurant for cooking it to perfection. I ate it all and was still hungry for dessert. Yeah, it is rich but appropriately so.
The lamb was also cooked perfectly with a lovely subtle wine sauce and the accompaniments were tip-top awesome. Creamy and delicate scalloped potatoes, sauteed spinach and a very nice - if a bit spicy to my taste - ratatouille.
I also had some Roquefort just because. 

The only disappointment was dessert. That creme brulee was a big miss as far I am concerned. The texture was very very wrong. Sickeningly firmer than it should be (it should melt in the mouth, not feel like Jello) and you could tell right away it was off because the sugar top did not crack as it should when we put our spoons to it.

In the end, this was a very very enjoyable meal with, as it should be, as highlight two wonderful entrees. It had enough small disappointments that it does not deserve five stars but it is a solid four stars. We definitely had trouble digesting afterward so maybe you should order more strategically and eat lighter but it was a wonderful dinner.
author: Dorian S.

description: I've been dining at LeCentral for over 30 years. It's like the old suede coat in the back of my closet - comfortable, unpretentious and hasn't changed a bit. The French brothers that owned it have long retired but the new owners have retained the menu - my favorites being the Chicken - roasted or cold - or the Cold Poached salmon. Always a butter lettuce salad to start and wonderful sweet French baguette and sweet butter to accompany everything. I never have a problem making a reservation and the staff are always kind and attentive.
author: Hotel B.

description:
I want to keep this one simple:

1) Great happy hour. $1 oysters were delicious. 

2) Awesome little bar to hang out at during off hours.

3) The quintessential French bistro ambience que j'adore.

4) A fantastic bartender. 

5) The ultimate highlight: They served my dirty and dry vodka martini in a chilled glass, with the liquid in a separate carafe kept on ice. Keeping the drink cold made a tremendous difference in the taste.
author: Joie D.

description: I did some searching and ended up having dinner at Le Central Bistro which was just a short walk from my hotel. I looked through the menu for a short period of time before deciding on the crab cakes for my first course. The presentation was phenomenal. I just wish the flavours were equally as stunning. The burr blanc was kind of mediocre, though I must admit the crab cake was very meaty and a good portion of crab. Everything just seemed slightly under-seasoned. Things picked up with the second course. The Beef Bourguignon was a perfect marriage of tender beef and red wine. The carrots were soft yet not overdone and it was a very comforting dish for the slighty chilly northern California evening. Things continued to get better with the creme brulee. I'm not much for sweets but this one was done perfectly. I'm usually sort of unimpressed by creme brulee, by this one was perfectly creamy and not overpowering with sweetness. The smooth vanilla texture went along well with the tasty caramelized sugar. Admittedly I am a sucker for caramel.
author: Zorin D.

description: A classic favorite downtown SF. Expensive, but consistently a wonderful experience. Vegetarian-friendly, good service, and a classy ambiance. Definitely try their french fries!
author: Jane D.

description:
This place is mediocre at best. It has an odd smell upon entering and the tables are too close together. The service is minimal and the gentleman clearing the table looked at me and said "you done" Not exactly what I expect from a French restaurant.

I would not go back to this restaurant!
author: Lisa L.

description: Was so looking forward to entertaining an important client for a late lunch at this legendary San Francisco institution. Never again. The service was unexceptional; the steak tartare was absolutely flat, bland and completely lacking flavor. I sent it back and whatever they did was no help.The tarte tatin was barely room temperature and smothered in a treacly caramel sauce. I used to live in France and have had better food in a hole in a French wall.
author: Meryl K.

description: As always, fabulous. From cocktails and wines to appetizers and entrees. My wife and I don't usually do desserts. Le Central is our favorite San Francisco restaurant. The staff is outstanding and always do the right thing. Our last visit a week ago as we live in Florida so don't get here but about five or six times a year, we had the joy of sitting two tables away from the Mayor Willy Brown. He's a terrific man, polite and interesting. We only addressed him as we were leaving and simply said how nice it was to see him.  We visit here often and never miss this place. The specials are winners and my last was steak tartar while my wife had the leek tart and we added salads and the pomme frites. This time I had a rum and coke and my wife had a house recommended white which was out of this world. In the past we had sat in the dinning room, at the bar, but this time at a table on the bar side. It is now where we will prefer to sit from now on. One thing that's special here is the attention to detail and the standard house dishes, one of which is cassoulet. Its the best we have ever had including visits to France. Amazingly, they had a hamburger on the menu this last time. I was tempted but then thought where would I have some of the other dises if I had this. Not to be missed is the Escargot and the French Onion Soup ... tho we don't often finish all the dishes we order we like to taste them. Finally, the classic French roast chicken. Wonderful. Now back here in Florida we are yet planning our next visit to San Francisco via Las Vegas and already taste the wonderful entrees at Le Central.
author: Frank S.

description:
There's a reason why this place has been around for so long.

Portions were a nice size, the lamb was really tender and it actually a whole rack. This is very unlike many places in SF, where you'll be lucky to get 3 little bones for more than you'll pay here. I'd recommend it to anyone.

For an appetizer we had the Escargots de Bourgogne. If you're into this sorta thing, which clearly why would anyone not want to eat snails, then this was also phenomenal. Just throw on enough garlic on to anything and it will taste great. In all honesty, these were REALLY good.

Service was quick, manager was nice, even though my dad was being typically annoying.

I'll be back!
author: Josh D.

description:
Having lived in san Francisco and now along the  Peninsula, I have passed Le Central numerous times over the years but never dined there. Several Saturday's ago, my wife and I were passing through the neighborhood and decided to stop there to eat.

The wait staff was pleasant and the food quite good and reasonably priced.  The setting was quiet and a nice break from the hustle and bustle just beyond the large windows. 

I gave the restaurant 3 stars not for any reason other than it is more like a nice café rather than a fine restaurant.  I wouldn't take someone there for a "fine dining" experience.
author: john f.

description: We just wanted to have dinner near our hotel, and there're 3 French restaurants on the same street. Only Le Central has English menu outside & claims to be the oldest French bistro in SF, so we gave it a try. We ordered filet mignon & goat cheese/leek tart. Both were very good. The source in filet mignon is abundant in a good way & very tasty. I've never done quiche with source (balsamicy), but they tasted so good together. Last not but least is cocktail. Though they don't have cocktail menu, the bartender can make custom cocktail. The chocolate martini we ordered came in small bottle in a small bucket of ice with a chocolate piece in martini glass. We're surprisingly impressed with Le Central. Highly recommended.
author: Keiko M.

description:
My friends brought me here after the musical, FELA.  I had always noticed this restaurant, but never ventured in... my loss!  The place is romantic, bustling with laughter with the aromas of delicious foods.... I had the mushroom soup and 1/2 Chicken, and everyone at my table tried my soup and they all agreed, it was the BEST ever... And the chicken was mouth watering... I cannot wait to go back!  Oh, and the staff are fun, professional and knowlegeable.  I love this place!
Joanna, Sonoma, Ca
author: Joanna M.

description: Been here twice in the last couple of months. Their food is super yummy but a little on the expensive side. I took my fiancee here for our 3 yr anniversary celebration a few months ago & he really liked it. I got the Jumbo Shrimp Risotto which I have to say is AMAZING! very creamy, rich, thick & the shrimp are truly JUMBO. I gave them a 4 star because their server that particular day was to say the least an ASSHOLE! gave him a 10% tip just to be nice, but he should not have gotten anything at all this his snotty self. Anyways asides that I recommend this place. Without tip the bill came out to about $90 & with tip it came out to $100 exact.
author: Dessa S.

description: Very solid traditional French bistro fare.
author: Michael R.

description:
Our Tuesday night, 6:15PM reservations weren't needed. The place was near empty. 

Plus: Tasty, well presented food. Excellent timing from the kitchen. A little bit of San Francisco funk.

Minus: Our waiter tried to be a bit aloof, but I treated him like an old friend, and he warmed up. A tad bit pricey, $90 including tip for two entrees, two appetizers (no drinks, no dessert). 

Overall, pretty good.

If you need a night out from the kitchen, or a place where where non-foodies can relax and enjoy some pretty darn good chow, give it a try.
author: Art R.

description: We dine here at least monthly and always have the Nicoise Salad which is superb.   They make it with a tuna confit.  The decor is quite reminiscent of a Parisian café And they sell all sorts of international magazines and newspapers so be sure to pick one up to read with your meal. To make it easier they will put it on your bill. The staff is quite attentive and friendly and it's always a lively scene.  It's right off of Union Square so a great location for a business lunch or a break from shopping. We often bring visitors here for lunch.
author: Henry H.

description: Food is consistent, great for the price, unpretentious, one of the few traditional French restaurants left in town. Much better than Cafe Claude and Cafe de la Presse.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I am gonna keep this short because this place is simply awesome. An eclectic group allowing you to dress fancy or casual. You can sit in a booth or at a table. 

All in all, a romantic little hole in the wall_kind of expensive, but what isn't?? I guess..
author: Greg A.

description:
My best friend and I decided to come here for our Christmas lunch. She works far away in the marina and needs to drive to downtown, so Sutter-Stockton garage was the best place for her to park. Long story short - we chose Le Central for its proximity to the stupid garage. 

Moral #1: Never, ever choose a place to eat by its proximity to parking.

We did not have a reservation. It turns out that walk-ins are not welcome at Le Central. Vraiment? (translation: WTF? Really?). The host was a stark Asian guy, whose English was suitable for selling fake Fendi handbags in Chinatown. After telling us there were no free tables (restaurant was half empty at that time), he very rudely asked us how much time we needed for lunch. He could only seat us if we promised to be out of there by 1 o'clock. 

Moral #2: When this happens to you, walk away. There are plenty of eateries that want you as a customer.

The place is very small and to maximize the revenue per square foot, tables are so close to each other that I was brushing my neighbor's sleeve every time I reached for my bread. To be seated, the table needed to be completely moved forward then moved back. So if my friend needed to use the restroom, she obviously was out of luck.

Moral #3: When you see that the patrons of the restaurant are pipe smoking, plaid flannel suit wearing, snobbish Sherlock Holmes wannabes, walk away. Fast. 

Anyway, the food was very good. Real French-style gourmand-worthy treats.

Message to the employees of the joint: dudes, lose the attitude. You are not in Paris. You are next to Chinatown.
author: Tatyana S.

description:
I really really wanted to like this place! But all I can think about is- my hard-earned mulah went to waste, uhhhhhh..... sigh.............gasp!!

We went there thinking DAT is a good way to experience some pricey yummy French food. Sorry to say the yummy aspect was not there. 
- We had the French Onion soup and Crab cake for appetizer (nothing extraordinary)
- Grilled Filet of Salmon Beurre Nantais and Flat Iron Steak with Bordelaise Sauce (utterly disappointing)
- Lets say the best part of the meal was dessert. 

And my heart cried while signing that cc receipt.... sigh again.....
author: Kanwal A.

description: Last week Thursday I went to Cafe de la Presse but passed by Le Central. After having lunch at Cafe de la Presse I wanted to have lunch at Le Central. I did some research on their menu. I was interested in the cassoulet as it had the Le Central namesake on the dish. For any restaurant if it has their namesake restaurant on their dish it usually means it is one of their specialties. This past Thursday I went to Le Central to initially have the cassoulet only as I never had it before. The mistake was also ordering their french onion soup. The first time I had french onion soup was at Kincaid's Restaurant in Burlingame. It was really good because I liked the thick cheese on top. I hoped Le Central's would be as good. It was ok, but the disappointment was that the french onion soup and cassoulet were the same size. My fault as I should have asked the waiter how big was the cassoulet in comparison to the french onion soup. Also I should have stuck to my intention and just ordered the cassoulet only as a main dish and would have saved about $9. The cassoulet was really good but I did expect it to be in a bigger dish especially due to the price. I hadn't intended to ordered the dessert. However the waiter gave me a menu and noticed the soufflé glacée had the Le Central namesake on the dish so I decided to try it. It was pretty good and enjoyed it more than the French onion soup. A pretty good place to have a quick lunch from work.
author: Gerald R.

description:
Enjoyed the beef stew;  nice ambiance. small servings.
tight seating. Convienant if you work near montgomery/california. decent value, will go back. Where do i find Tete de Veau?
author: Bert K.

description:
My mom has been whining for many months about Le Central for lunch. However, as a member of the working class, I cannot afford to take 1 1/2 hours for lunch during the week. So we compromised on a Saturday lunch in August. Mama was not able to sit next to Willie Brown, but sacrifices must be made. She LOVED her salad nicoise, I had the cream of mushroom soup and a big bowl of hot, and salty pomme fritte. The pomme fritte was the bext bowl of potato strings I've had in a long time. Way better than Citizen Cake, fo sho. We skipped the dessert but did have coffee. It took a bit of time to get our half caf/half decaf but that's because the bus person was making FRESH just for us. Friends, that's service, and the reason I completely overtipped. 

Mom and decided to use the ladies before leaving. We asked, and the bar man pointed the way and said that if the ladies was in use, that it was okay to use the men's. and that's what we did. The men's room was very clean, and large. 

I will definitely go back again for lunch. I paid $50 + tip for a geat meal and outstanding service for me and my mom. 

Le Central is probably good for small'ish group 6 - 8 people. I've heard that it isn't a good place for children, and while I will agree with that generally for dinner or a long lunch, I witnessed well-behaved children enjoying the pomme fritte so it can be done.
author: Bronwyn W.

description: French name, French wine, French menu. Needs a little more French pop. Staff is attentive and polite. Patrons have fun. Famous past. It's all about the food. You decide.
author: Lawrence V.

description: Great steak au poivre!
author: Lawrence S.

description:
Can you say cassoulet? Le Central has a very warm, inviting, and totally-date-worthy environment with friendly and super attentive service. My friend had the plat du jour, crusted sea bass ($23) over a slightly sweet pea puree and tomato sauce. I had the house specialty cassoulet ($19) and was surprised at how well the entire dish comes together in your mouth. The tender, falling apart meat with perfectly cooked white beans are explosive with home-cooked flavor; perfect for a cold winter night. We ended our dinner with two desserts: chocolate pot de creme and the chocolate mousse (both $9). Each had their own level of chocolate and unique texture, amazing!

I will definitely go back to try more of their refined menu. Enjoy!
author: Lauren J.

description:
I will say one thing good about this place before launching into my tirade: the ambience of the restaurant did in fact remind me of France, which made me all warm and tingly inside. Our server was friendly and made us feel very welcome. And the crab cake was delicious, albeit lukewarm.

However, the food in general was extremely expensive for what you get out of it. For example, we ordered a prosciutto with melon appetizer. Sounds exotic, right? Highly underwhelming. It was literally three slices of average prosciutto on top of half a cantaloupe not even sliced well.

Then there was the $16 cheese platter, which was five small pieces of cheese and a few grapes presented on a depressingly bare plate. The brie was rancid, and I'm not using the word in a slang insult way. It was literally rotten cheese gone bad. Not wanting to be rude, we asked the waiter what kind of brie it was - after all, we weren't cheese connoisseurs and maybe there is brie out there that's supposed to taste weird...? The server went to the kitchen to ask, came back with red cheeks, and said in his best waiter voice, "Why yes, it is double ripened President brie, accent on the E". 

As in President cheese, the generic, mass-produced cheese you can get in bulk at Costco?? 

So to summarize, the chef phoned in his performance and we paid $16 for rancid Costco cheese. Our total bill was more than the food was worth, and we left feeling like we'd been lied to.

Later that night, we went to get drinks and dessert at Absinthe. Now THAT is a restaurant that's worth the money. Le Central could take some pointers from them.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Thought from seeing all the old folks in here regularly that this place would have some classic charm. It did, but it also had a ton of kids being loud. Maybe the nearby hotels dragged them in. My steak was good, the wine was great. My dates seabass was not good.
author: Karl G.

description:
I would like to start by saying that I would typically have mentioned these things to the waiter or manager, however we were never asked "How is everything?" or "How was your meal?" and I did not want to push anything with the waiter who did not seem to care. But as my Parisian husband put it, the rude service really made him feel like he was back home.

As my husband is from Paris, we frequent french restaurants, and we had seen Le Central on many a list of good french restaurants in the city. We were in the area last night (a thursday night) and got a table around 9pm. There were 2 other parties in the restaurant. We ordered: Duck Rillette (was nothing special; could buy higher quality at our local deli; I don't think they make it in house); Boudin Noir (too much cartilage, which I couldn't chew and left on a pile in my plate; one of the sausages was burnt); Steak Tartar (okay, but the toasted bread was burnt. We felt it was waaay overpriced at $29); With most of our food still on the plate, its a shame that nobody ever asked if something was wrong? Especially when there was a pile of cartilage on one plate.

I understand that we were one of the last tables of the night, but with servers chewing on something (gum? food?) and loudly shutting down starting at 9:30pm, it just was not an enjoyable evening. We called over our waiter and gave him our card, and left as quickly as possible. As we headed home we kept scratching our heads about what could of been going on, because we had heard such good things about this restaurant. Did they change owners? 

Bottom line: next time we will walk the extra block to Cafe Bastille
author: Jessica B.

description: The space was nice, service not bad, but the food was nothing great.
author: Susan A.

description: The atmosphere and service were great, but the food was underwhelming to say the least. I had the fries and chicken and the chicken was slightly over cooked and tough. I mean how hard is it to get chicken right? Over all, not bad, but since its SF, you can easily find plenty of competition that will deliver a knockout punch.
author: John Z.

description:
We've dined here many times.  We dine out a lot.  So we have some degree of authority and reference.  This restaurant pleases us consistently.  Were there again two nights ago.  Wife had the rack of lamb which we both agreed was one of the best ever after I sampled it.  I had the salmon which was cooked to perfection (most other places overcook and dry it out.)

Wine list was short, but what they offered was well selected.

Service was great as usual.  Attentive without being intrusive.

This place will always be among our regular haunts.
author: Les G.

description:
Was at the restaurant Friday night and it was wonderful.  I spent the summer in Paris 2 years ago and this gem of a restaurant took me right back.  It's decor is authentic, food delicious, and service wonderful.

Sat on the bar side with a group of 4.  The bar was full and only a few tables free but I did not feel crowded as some reviewers have mentioned.  In fact, this is just like restaurants on Ile St-Louis where I stayed and added to the authenticity.

The food was amazing.  We started with escargot, duck rillettes, and herb crusted goat cheese.  Followed it with the cassoulet (over 13,000 days old and still going strong!), rack of lamb, and Dayboat Scallops Provençale.  Everything was flavored perfectly and not a bit was left at the end of our meal.  The serving sizes were very generous, and even though we were stuffed we had to try the creme brulee and we were so glad we did.

Servers were great.  Fast, efficient, attentive and generous with the wine pouring.   Also, you can tell that regulars come to this place time and time again.  We heard servers greet people by name and ask after family members.  This is the kind of place you want to come back to time and time again.  I know I will.  Especially for that lamb and ratatouille.
author: Carolyn S.

description: Disappointing. Not much in your plate, too noisy. Dessert (tarte tatin) wasn't good at all!
author: Chiara R.

description: Went here expecting great things based on other reviews.  The food was so-so.  Not bad but not great.   Had the cassoulet as it seems to be the house special.  The service made me think I was in France as it was inconsistent and rude. Actually, the French are better.  Save your money and time and go somewhere else.
author: Brian F.

description:
The menu is a bit basic as far as French food goes. There are a few of the classics, but everything else is pretty generic. What they do have though is very good. My steak was perfect and I'm told my wife's fish was equally delicious.

What ruins the meal though is the service. We were ignored completely by our waiter (Scott) who fawned over the table next to us. Over all, it was a decent meal, but I shouldn't have to get up to track the waiter down after waiting 15 minutes for him to run my credit card. Either hire more staff or fire Scott.
author: John P.

description:
We went here for the Dine About Town dinner, and it was just eh...the dessert (lemon souffle) was the best thing on the DAT menu.

The waiter was lurking for most of the meal, and was very controlling about everything, from the placement of my silverware, and moving it to where HE wanted to move it, to telling me to wait by the door, when I was meeting my dining partner at the bar. Wow.

Okay, so it's a good thing I went in using Dine About Town, because I wouldn't have picked the restaurant, otherwise. Now I know...I won't go back.
author: Pam W.

description:
I don't know what to say...I went here and found that the food was blah,,,,The filet was OK to good but not great.  The crab cake was one piece for $10 but just Ok. Ambiance: People that are older (50-60)  Decor was quaint and nice (kind of like something in a cruise ship)  But something was dead, off and twilight zoney...I will not be coming here again.  I give it two stars b/c I have been to worse.  
The Cassoulet was mushy with a lot of canneloni beans (no sauce), no flavor. The service was attentive and polite, It was just weird to come here,,,,maybe it was latural gray lighting from outside...Just say this, the food is better at Cheesecake Factory...
author: Q A.

description: What a pretentious , arrogant staff.  We were walking by and saw the awesome menu out front. Upon entering the staff was unwelcoming, unaccommodating and the vibe was superior. As a local I was very disappointed in my people.
author: James B.

description:
This restaurant is considered old SF and you get that feeling once you walk in.  
Happy hour isn't bad there.  M-F from 4pm to 6pm. $5 wine, beer and a couple drink specials. $1 Oysters on a half shell.  A good end of the day refresher and start to your dinner.
The Cassoulet has said to be cooking since the day the place opened.  It is a type of bean, stew with duck meat and thickened tomato soup.  The server gave us a sample after I asked what a Cassolet was once I read a sign outside that it had been cooking for some 13K days.  
They have daily specials that are written on a chalkboard and placed at your table.  The server will just read them to you but won't describe them, you have to ask.
It was the first time we ate French cuisine and I have no complaints.  We didn't think it cost very much.  It was less than $100 for 2 people, 2 appetizers (French Onion Soup and a Crab cake, which was served with the most tasteful sauce), 2 cocktails (Wine and a Jameson), 2 entrees (Chicken and Prawns).  
If I am in the mood for French food again I'll come back.  It is conveniently located near my work and isn't a bad walk.
author: Grace P.

description:
3.5. FH and I ate here last week for DAT. we rolled in a bit past 8 and were seated in a corner booth. he had the french onion soup, salmon, and the chocolate mousse, i had the crabcake, beef bourginon, and lemon souffle. 

everything was fantastic. the beef was SO tender, it fell apart when i touched it with my fork. and the portion was MASSIVE. both of us ate some and i couldn't finish it all.

service was good - cute little place. although the odd couple talking about their sex preferences next to us kinda took away from it - we still had a good time.
author: laura f.

description:
I want to love this place, but the last couple of times I've been for lunch have honestly not been very good. Today my rillettes were cold and awfully pasty, more like a pate in texture than good shredded duck meat. And the salade nicoise was a bit underwhelming with limp green beans and what I swear was canned tuna. Add in a lost reservation and some mediocre service and I was wishing I'd gone up the street to Cafe de la Presse instead.

Le Central can be good, particularly the cassoulet. And I love the tradition and role it places in San Francisco, want to support it. Maybe they just need to freshen up the cooking a bit.
author: Nelson M.

description:
I've seen this place for years, but never had a chance to eat here.  Tonight, we decided to go for some French food, so why not try it finally?

Hubby started off with a mixed green salad with Roquefort cheese - he absolutely loved it.  I had to have the escargot.  Piping hot, fabulous garlic and oil that you just have to dip with French bread.

For entrees, I had the cassoulet.  Delicious!  White beans, sausage and duck served in a little iron pot.  My husband had the risotto with prawns.  Risotto was average, but the prawns were so succulent.  You really can really taste the difference with fresh seafood.

For dessert, I had the creme brulee.   Except for the powdered sugar on top (which I've never seen anyone do on this dessert before), I thoroughly enjoyed my selection.  There wasn't any left over, let's put it that way.  My husband had a slice of lemon tart with fresh whipped cream on the side, with a small pile of raspberries.  He said it was very good, but could be a little more lemony.

On the whole, we really enjoyed the food there.  The bar was the focal point of the evening.  There were only about three - four tables of diners this Friday night.
author: Denise M.

description:
We hit up this place last Friday night when we were in SF for the weekend.  We found the place cozy and comfortable.  Although the place started out slow, it was pretty hoppin by 8ish.  It was full of what seemed to be locals -- which was our favorite part.  We try to not be tourists when is SF.

I had the Halibut -- it was HELLA GOOD!!!  The hubby had the Osso Bucco (sp?)... really, really good.  Thu funny thing was we were the last 2 people to get these dishes because they only had 1 left of each... we scooped them up quickly.  The Halibut was so, so good I could have licked my plate clean.  I've never been to Paris but if this is what a french bistro is supposed to fee like... I can't wait to go.  Needless to say, we'll be back.
author: Kelly F.

description:
Did the business lunch thing here recently.  I swear a sport coat's required to get a table, but hey, it's nice to dress up and feel important sometimes.

While the prices were a little steep (I guess $30 for a filet is reasonable for downtown SF, but at lunch when the portions are noticeably smaller?).  Barack, where you at w/ my stimulus check?!?

Overall, my steak was juicy and flavorful, and my friend's plates were clean in a hurry.  I didn't try their dishes, but we did share some prosciutto e melone - very tasty.

Final words of advice, sit down on the early side if you want to get in and out (relatively) quickly.  Around 12:15, I think a shuttle from the Embarcadero Center dropped off about 20 suits.
author: Forrest W.

description: Me and my fiance love this place. This is a go-to place whenever we have a date night in San Francisco.
author: Amanda A.

description: This is actually a pretty good restaurant .For dinner had excellent ,garlicky escargot , good cassoulet and tasted a first rate coq au vin.They tended to run out of specials.The off note was a rather weird waiter who over poured wine and seemed to think he was clever.Still it's a good place.
author: John K.

description:
My bucket list of restaurant to try.

We took advantage of the DAT on a Sat night.
I sat in  Willie Brown's designated seat.

We give the restaurant 5 stars for ambiance, it truly has the old school
feel of a established  French restaurant.
Also give our Waiter and Lady Maître  and service staff  5 stars.

Unfortunately the Kitchen falls short in execution of its Food / Taste department.
 
Our Steak, Chicken and Cassoulet had no seasoning  and needed salt and pepper. What happen to the old french way of heavy butter sauces?

A big Bad, the Sea Bass was late and undercooked, Waiter and Maître did comp the entree and offer a dessert also. Which was a Class Act !!! 
 
I am willing to give it a another try in the future, if the Kitchen improves.
The fellow Yelpers who gave it 2 stars regarding taste was correct.
author: Food Sage W.

description:
This place definitely serves a mean roast chicken, the green beans, and asparagus were truly amazing. We even ordered a bottle of white wine, and topped the evening with a chocolate cake from Minette. All of this was delicious, but you definitely get back to reality when you see your 230+ bill for 5 people. 

This is definitely a place for some quality food, don't get me wrong, but if you must factor in price, it may not seem all worth it. You decide. Although, pomme frites, even though they are pomme frites are not worth any additional cash... but for the company I had tonight, it was well worth every penny spent! I would definitely come back for great service and attention, and great company.
author: Angela C.

description:
We stayed at Union Square  this week, and walked in the general direction of Belden Alley, thinking we'd end up there. We stopped to look at menus at Cafe De La Presse, then Le Central, and were pleasantly surprised to find that Le Central is not as expensive as I'd always assumed.
