We had a quiet table on Tuesday night, excellent service, and everything we ordered was fantastic. The atmosphere was intimate and comfortably elegant. 

The maitre'd who seated us, who we were with for all of one minute, impressed us both with his attentiveness to the arrangement on our table after we were seated, bringing the salt, pepper and small floral arrangement neatly to the far corner opposite our seats. A small but elegant gesture. 

Our waiter, Scott, was friendly, attentive, and very knowledgeable about the menu, answering questions about preparation. He  arranged for a salad we were sharing to be served on two separate plates, something both of us appreciated. Both Scott and the busboy knew how to serve and remove plates properly, something that we've seen plenty of clumsiness around lately at other restaurants. 

Everything (table, food, service, vibe) was impeccable yet natural and relaxed, not uptight at all. High points: the onion tart, the cassoulet, and the grilled salmon. We look forward to returning later in the summer.
author: Mary P.

description:
This restaurant was my first ever Yelp review and I was overly critical before, so I am updating my review. 

I came back recently for a business lunch and thoroughly enjoyed my meal, the service and my dining companions. Yes, there is a limited selection for a vegetarian, but that is my problem/issue, not the restaurant's. 

This time around, I had the cheese tart with figs and a salad. The tart had a perfect combo of cheeses, was light and fluffy and the crust was fantastic, firm and not at all soggy. The figs were a great touch and had some sort of cream piped onto them. The salad had a nice balsamic vinaigrette. Some of the leaves were a bit wilted, but still a good salad. 

On a more interesting note, I ran into Willie Brown on my way to the restrooms. He's a frequent diner here and it was great to meet him! Although I was a bit foolish and said to him, "Hey! You're Willie Brown!". Duh! I think he knows who he is!
author: Caroline C.

description:
Real bistro fare that isn't shy about butter and cream - check.
Hard-core Vietnamese waiters kickin' it old school, Colonial style - check.
Mini-chalkboard menu brought to your tiny table - check.
Willie Brown sitting at his window table every Friday for lunch - check.

I've been here for lunch and dinner at least a dozen times and I am always the youngest person in the house... by a solid 2 decades.  It's loud, boistrous, and the seating arrangements border on claustrophobic.

Duck rillettes.  Two words that keep me coming back.  Oh, that... and "duck aspic".  Which is served cubed and generously scattered across the serving plate... When no one is looking, I scoop a few pieces into my mouth, and let my tongue play over them as they yield and melt across my taste buds.  

Why can't I buy duck-flavored jello at the store?  

This gorgeous slab of decadent... duckness... liberally spread across sliced table bread and sprinkled with some gelee... followed by a mini-bite of cornichon is as close to lunch-hour heaven as it gets.  For $7.50, and without risking a misdemeanor, that is.  

And that's my appetizer!  I also adore the leeks vinaigrette, the sexy salad nicoise and when I'm feeling like a splurge (which is often) I'll have the Crab Cake Beurre Blanc.  

The latter is a portly, fist-sized crustacean-cake that arrives crisped and coated lightly in bread crumbs... basking in a freshly-poured puddle of buerre blanc.  While this item is listed as an appetizer, if you start with something else... and share a few bites of your fellow diner's dishes... the crab cake can serve as an entree. 

I, personally am over tiny little appetizers... like the "lobster ceviche" that I ordered at Nobu back in 1999 for $20 and was nothing more than a short stack of tortilla chips with a paltry sprinkling of dry lobster crumbs between them. Not that I'm holding a grudge or anything.  

Okay - back to my crab cake:  it's refreshingly free of fillers and chunks of not-crab.  It is perfect with a swipe of the beurre blanc and should be consumed reverently, at a leisurely pace.  

So... maybe this place is a bit stodgy... but between the authentic bistro fare, which includes seasonal delicacies and a charcuterie selection that never leaves me wanting... I always hit that gustatory sweet spot.  

Look for me if you stop by for lunch; I'll be the only other person who doesn't have an AARP membership, blissfully attending to my rillette or pate de campagne.
author: Kim D.

description:
Really nice place for dinner for 3.

Appetizers:

Escargots - Excellent, good balance of salt, butter, garlic
Saucisson Chaud - Not overpowering, with a nice sauce and potatoes
Rillettes de Canard - great.  Just like you'd get in France

Main plates:

Rack of lamb - terrific.  Perfectly cooked and seasoned
Skate, sauce grenoblaise - excellent, this was a special
Cassoulet "Le Central" - melted in my mouth w/ duck confit and sausage

Dessert :

Pear tart - not too sweet with a flaky crust.  Exactly what I wanted.

Wine: 

A 2003 from Margaux.  Quite good.
author: Justin C.

description:
I really wanted to try the OLD OLD thousand year old stew! But for some reason when it was being described to me i lost my appetite. Amish cake-Old Stew--sounds like a trip to the bathroom--many of them. 

So i played it safe and went with sea bass which was delicious! Could have definitely come with more rissoti--I hate and love leaving a place with my plate wiped clean which leads me to believe it was delicious but just not enough. 

Great ambience, seemed authentically french to me.

Omg and I love how they present desserts--they have a tray of them--smart! cannot resist to them then. Creme brulee-chocolate cake, tiramisa--HEAVENLY!
author: Amy S.

description:
I have lived in San Francisco for 17 years and I had one of the worst dining experience in my memory last night at Le Central. 

From the moment my girlfriend and I walked in we were treated like we were riff raff. Perhaps because we are young and most of their guests are over 50. 

The host looked confused as to where to sit us despite our reservation and that the place was only half full. So he puts us snug next to another couple despite available tables for 4 which never were filled in the course of our visit. 

So it starts like this.....The waiter bumped my chair twice while serving other parties before finally coming to our table. He was also rude when I asked him some details about the menu as if I was holding him up from doing his job.

We asked for water 4 times! From the time when we sat down from the host, then the busboy twice and the waiter once.

All of this to me is forgivable if the food is good. It was terrible.

My girlfriend ordered the roast chicken and pommes frittes which featured a glop of unfrozen spinach, along with a dry chicken and yup, you guessed, it soggy fries.

The dish I ordered was worse. AVOID THE CASSOULET if you insist on going here. It's a pot full of dry white beans and few pieces of leftover chicken and two slices of sausage that cost $18.50. I think I would have been better served by a tin of Spam!

It get's better. My girlfriend and I love creme brulee and in a hope to redeem the meal we ordered it. Well, it was bad. Too many eggs, and too soft. It barely felt like creme brulee. It was like sugar omelette.

I don't like to write poor reviews on any place here on Yelp. However, for a restaurant that has been around as long as Le Central, I am compelled to be honest right here and let people know that if you want dry food and bad service Le Central might be right for you.
author: Matthew S.

description:
Classy and elegant place where people were in proper attire like attending a business dinner. Ambiance was quiet and low key. The deco was good-- semi-dim lights to mellow out the evening.

Food was also low key and simple. My prawns risotto was pretty good. Dessert was passable, a bit heavy and was pre-made way earlier and lacked the excitement.

Service was a bit confusing as we were served by multiple people instead of 1 who took the order and 1 server.
author: T L.

description:
It's got an old-world French-restaurant-in-SF vibe.  You've got the old French waiters, an obviously aged dining space and a view of the city streets.

Not too good in terms of service or dining.  I had the rabbit, whose bones nearly scratched out my tonsil.  The waiter stared at me for moments on end when I asked him for my meal and was in general a cross between distracted and rude.  I felt self-conscious eating with him around.

The presumed owner, or the owner's son, came by and took ahold of our table in a proprietary manner so he could pull it to the side for another couple to squeeze in next to us.  It was fine and all, but I'm always a little stunned to have my meal dragged away from me without an apology or explanation.

I had creme brulee for dessert.  It was just like the one I made during a let's-bootleg-dessert! spree I went through last year: burnt sugary top, rubbery cold custard.

Le Central costs too much for what you get and I walked away feeling dissatisfied and moody.
author: Angela N.

description:
Dont waste your time thinking you are going to a french restaurant here 
mediocre food and service empty on a friday night at 8 pm bad smell when you enter the place Cassoulet a glob of beans and fat with a suspicious sausage at the bottom.... stale bread ....
author: didi c.

description:
First off, do not bring your children here. This is an adult restaurant for people who want to have drinks and really good French bistro food and do not want to listen to spoiled brats screaming at the next table. 

Whew. Sorry, had to vent. Truly good food. Very experienced staff who know how to take care of you provided you do not walk in wearing torn jeans with your shirt hanging out, and then demand that they change what you want to order in 10 different ways. Vegetarians need not apply. Excellent bartender and good wine list, and the wine by the glass is often a treat. Excellent steak au poivre, roast chicken, cold salmon, and the pomme frites are the best this side of Paris. Always a good dessert tray if the sweet thing is your thing. Good people watching.

My only minor complaint after eating here regularly for years is that the early lunch and dinner food can sometimes be undercooked - almost like the kitchen staff is not up and running in time for the opening hour - hence 4 stars instead of 5. A suggestion is to eat lunch after 12:30 and dinner after 6:00. Other than that, it's a terrific place with nearby parking in the Sutter Stockton garage.

And don't forget - leave the rugrats at home.
author: Dexter N.

description:
Christmas, 2007.  50 drunken Santa Clauses coming from the Irish Bank.  Damn - If the real one is in there, I'm thinking, Christmas is doomed.  Dave and I quickly duck into Le Central to avoid thier beligerent ho ho ho's and cracks about the reindeer.

Suddenly I am transformed into an expat somewhere in the south of France.  The bar is a perfect mix of interesting people, freindly and knowledgable bartenders (we had a great discussion about Frenet-Bianca).  And the food isn't bad either.  The Escargots and French onion soup is great.  The place has a homey atmosphere that translates into plain old good eats.

Next time you want to hide from an army of drunken Santas, hide in here.  They avoid it for some reason.
author: Randy C.

description:
I had dinner here not that long ago and I still remember the dishes.

Started with the butterleaf salad, braised leeks, and celery root remoulade (between us three). Both of my friends ordered the roasted chicken with pomme frites. I didn't try the chicken but from their faces, I think they approve.. But the pomme frites were so good.. Hot and crispy.. I ordered my favorite dish which was the boudin noir, fat black aromatic sausages. You can't get this anywhere else. Really juicy and yummy. 

Everything from ambiance, food, service, and cocktail was great.
author: Juliane N.

description: Le Central is my go-to place for lunch in the city.  I've been going there since the mid 1970's and it has yet to disappoint.  The cosmopolitans are excellent -- not the typical overly-sweet drink -- and also generous as you get a mini carafe to refill your glass.  The food is always excellent, but I especially love the poached salmon or sole.  The warm goat cheese salad and the beef tartar are also very good. The fries are ridiculously delicious.  It's a cozy place that's great for people watching.  The wait staff is not necessarily warm and fuzzy, but hey, it's a french restaurant and it has the status of an Old San Francisco restaurant favorite...
author: Sue J.

description:
Oh, Le Central -- a very sweet little bistro with a funny old crowd. I wouldn't come here with friends or on a date, but the family enjoys the atmosphere and sort-of-French food. The menu has some "Italian" items, which I find to be a bit strange. And the menu is very meat heavy.

I had the butternut squash soup, which was really good. Almost as good as the kind in the cardboard box from Trader Joe's. I really love that soup, especially the tomato one. Anyways, my fam had a bunch of fish and meat dishes. They liked them fine, nothing extraordinary. The quaint bistro atmosphere is cute -- a bit outdated.

Awesome German and French beer selection. The Bitburger was my favorite one. Our waiter was very nice and funny, but not super attentive. I think he had a lot of tables, so things were a bit slow, but we weren't in any hurry.
author: Syd V.

description:
Like almost everything else in SF, thanks to YOU, 
it used to be better.  Low-quality ingredients, riding on
a reputation, and depending heavily on tourists 
and ancient longtime customers who can't tell the food now is
so so at best.  Tasteless might be a better word.

And no French anyone anywhere at all.  Chinese owner and 
marginal white people staff.
author: harmonia b.

description:
Very uneven.  The first time I went, service was courteous, friendly, and timely.  The second time, they gave us a lousy table, we had to flag down the waiter for *everything*, the food was just so-so, and they brought the wrong bottle of wine (3 times as expensive as we ordered) which we didn't notice until the bill came. (Yeah, I know that one was my fault, but still.....$75 for a half bottle?)

Look elsewhere.  A rip-off downtown.  They're not any better because they don't have to be.
author: Steve S.

description:
Temperature inside was cold

Steak tartare was good

Chicken was greasy, and plate was piled with very overdone greasy fries that were bad. Plate had one tablespoon of spinach. Bad presentation, not enough vegetables at all. Very heavy and not the way I picture French food at all!

I don't think i would go back. Menu was overpriced compared to some of the other pleasant lunch places in the FiDi. 

Oh, company was good, she brought the French to the French restaurant.
author: Danielle V.

description: OMG is a very fitting comment for this restaurant. Everything we ordered are awesome. As soon as we mentioned we had a reservation, we were wisked to a table immediately. Service is great and the food came timely and smoothly. I'm more than satisfied with this restaurant. It's my first time dinning at Le Central and it won't be the last time.
author: Anita S.

description: My husband and I stayed across the street  for our anniversary. He wanted to go to the burger bar in Macy's and i was grossed out by the menu. I really wanted to go to La Central from the moment we checked into our room. We were greated by a quiet by smiling host, Our wait for a seat was only 5 minutes. Not being from the area, while everyone was very cold we just had a little chill, the restaurant for us was very very warm.  My husband was reluctant to have the ribeye because he hates rib eye. He has now fallen in love with ribeye thanks to the wonderful chef that night. I had scallops and pasta in a cream saucae and was in heaven. The food was amazing as was the service. It is very quaint and what I was looking for as our anniversary dinner. Very glad to dine there and cannot wait til our next visit to SF! I would recommend this restaurant .
author: Antoniett M.

description: If you go to an elegant French restaurant that charges $25-$30 for a main course, you expect great food, great service, and a beautiful ambiance. When we arrived, an unsmiling host quickly seated us. The waiter was perfunctory, speaking as little as possible, not telling us about the menu or the specials. When I joked to him, you should say "merci!" he said, "I am American," and walked away. That happened as soon as we were seated and set the tone. We split the crab cake for an appetizer (if I were the waiter I would have told us that there is only one crab cake; often in restaurants you get two, so it's a nice thing to split). It was good. But my shrimp were verging on dry and were not anything special. The saffron pea risotto was bland. My husband's steak was fine, but nothing special. His green beans were overcooked. We paid very special prices for a very mediocre experience.
author: Katherine E.

description: The rack of lamb was so tender, tasty and done to perfection.  On the other hand my friend's veal piccata was tuff and tasteless(doubt if it was real veal).  The service was very good.  Compliments to the bartender, Mat.  He is so polite, courteous and has a great personality.  He is a keeper!
author: mary f.

description: We love Le Central.  The staff and especially bartender, Nate, are very attentive and accommodating.   Playing dice at the bar has long been a fun tradition at Le Central and it's refreshing to see that it has withstood the test of time.  We are now back to being lunch time regulars here and adore the ambiance!
author: L. C. M. V.

description:
I was fairly suspicious of Le Central before going.
After all, this place has been around a long time and has quite a bit of history... good and bad.

Le Central's pretty proud of some of their more high-profile clients:  Wilkes Bashford, Herb Caen, and who could forget, former mayor "Slick" Willie Brown.  If you go at the right time, you may even see Slick Willie trying to proposition some nubile blonde in the corner, a definite Kodak moment.

Anyway, wifey and I pass by this place all the time and finally decided to step in to see what all the hubbub's about.

The maitre'd was delightful and accomodated our last-minute seating request without hesitation.  We sat in Herb Caen's table right next to the window so we could make fun of the tourists walking by...

The menu consists of straightforward and unpretentious French bistro fare.  Nothing wild or fancy, just solid classics.  Sometimes classic dishes are the best way to gauge the skill of the kitchen.

The standout dishes we had included a kickin' onion tart and a rich onion soup that any French grandma would be proud of.  Wifey's prawn risotto was nothing to sneer at either.

The staff was efficient and unobtrosive and prices were more than reasonable.

My assessment, great food and a fine experience.
I can see why Slick Willie brings the girlies here.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description: Dreadful. Ordered the roasted chicken pomme frites and returned them. Driest as chicken, ever, and the fries had absolutely no taste. Pepper and salt didn't save either.
author: S W.

description: This review is based on one salad... one salad that I cannot stop thinking about for the life of me! Get it please: the warm goat cheese salad... It has sweet figs, and buttery walnuts, and crispy bibb lettuce, and a warm, gooey, melty round of goat cheese atop a crunchy, toasty, fresh hunk of bread... the best part? The inside of the goat cheese manages to stay so flavorful and soft on the inside... believe me, this salad is magic!
author: Jamie K.

description: I am a hound for soups and the spinach soup was great. The cassoulet was outstanding, fantastic, superb. My friend liked her salade nicoise. The creme brulee was just right - the cream was delicious and I always like it when the burned parts cut the roof of my mouth (no joke, that's part of why I'm rating this place 5 stars). The service was warm, attentive, efficient. The place itself is great - lovely decor, very cozy and classy ambience, very nicely done with the brass rail and exposed brick, very clean and roomy. I am delighted and will return.
author: Michael E.

description: Dine about town 2013, looked for a place close to Jonny foleys dueling piano bar for a friends bday right after. Parking was easy, managed to snag a spot right across the street. The decor/ambiance was ok; if I had to describe it all in one word, "musty" comes to mind. I tried the herb crusted goat cheese salad with walnuts, the beef Bourguignon, and the berry tart with Creme fraiche for dessert. I also tried a bit of M's cassoulet, a white bean stew with slow cooked lamb and duck. The salad was so so, not well presented and the goat cheese came in one big block. The entrees tasted like standard French comfort food; I half expected the theme song from ratatouille to start playing in the background. I could only finish half of my beef as it was very filling. I think the cassoulet is better than the beef because the meat is more tender and the white bean stew is quite savory. Dessert was the best part, though not something I'd specifically come back here for. Service was meh. Overall, convenient location on Bush Street but probably will not be back.
author: Joyce H.

description:
I recently returned to the Bay area from years in SoCal.  Le Central used to be one of my favorites.  I was reminded of it when I saw it mentioned a couple of times in Willie Brown's column - apparently it is one of his favorites too.

To make a long story short, the wife and I went there last night.  This restaurant has nothing in common with the Le Central I once knew.  I expected, but did not get, an authentic French Brasserie meal.  Not even close.

The duck rillettes, a slice of pate cut into two pieces ($11) was OK, but Marcel & Henri's is significantly better.  The saucisson chaud ($10.50)had a nice sauce, but the sausage was not house made and the waitress had not a clue where it came from.

The onion soup ($9.00) was OK, but not the killer I expected and it was quite small.  My wife ordered a shrimp salad.  It cost more than $20 and consisted of nothing but a pile of chopped head lettuce with a few small shrimp on top with a slice of tomato that was so mushy it was inedible.  The waitress told us that the chef made it larger than usual.  I gather that "larger" means a lot of head lettuce.

The wine list was overpriced.  we had a bottle of vin ordinaire Macon Village for $32.  I bought some of it recently for $6 retail, so the markup was over 500% - not cool to say the least.

The place wasn't crowded and one waitress was assigned to cover our entire room.  Although the poor gal ran her a-s off, she was not able to keep up.  The maitre de just stood around watching - I couldn't believe that she didn't pitch in to help.

In summary, if you want to blow $100+ on lousy food and iffy service, this is the place for you.
author: Michael B.

description:
Old world charm, new world prices.

The salad nicoise was very tasty. I never would have ordered it if work wasn't paying for it.
author: Tamar N.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm friends with Louis (the most famous and fabulous server in this echelon of dining) , so that probably helps as far as receiving excellent service.

This place is old-fashioned European, slightly snobby, touristy and proud of it. So if you're a vegetarian or part of the 22-year-old hipster Asian crowd, you probably won't like it there. Go to Herbivore or be cool somewhere else.

If you like kitsch, hob-nobbing and artery-clogging food every once in a while, you've come to the right place. The Pommes are sinful, the Charcuterie is delightful (but definitely not light), and if you're in the know with the staff you can order a scallop salad that's generally not on the menu, which is delicious (and actually not even bad for you!).

And if you're really lucky you can make faces at Willie Brown while he's trying to be suave and important.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
The only reason why I give this place two stars is because of the attitude. It was so bad I thought I was in Paris. The place had a charm of a falling joint that you can tell was still living in it's ghost of former self. At any moment I thought Chef Gordon Ramsay was going to bust in on his show Kitchen Nightmares to condemn the place. So with that it was amusing.

BUT I WARN YOU. If you come for the food you'll be sorry. The only thing good was the bartender knows how to make a martini and the onion gratin was good. Everything else was prepared as top chef in 1966 was frozen in time and prepared meals with the same sensibilities. It was terrible. The most unimaginative preparation and presentation. This is NOT French food. 

The French cook with love. This was cooked with, "I hate my life". Seriously stay away if you are looking for a good meal. And to top it off it is pricey. Spent $150 for garbage. 

Come if you can afford to drop $150 and be amused at clueless attitude ridden service.
author: Scott B.

description: I have walked past Le Central a few thousand times and finally took the opportunity to have dinner there. Ordered the ossobuco special. Best ever. The cassoulet was amazing as well. Service was excellent. Staff very pleasant and accommodating. A really wonderful experience. Excellent value for the area.
author: Dave H.

description: Forgettable (except for the bad parts: a handful of flies buzzing the room, wines that tasted like grape juice, and the obese old men eating there).
author: Reality Check S.

description:
Definitely one of the most authentic French restaurants in San Francisco. I had the steak and pomme frits and savored every bite. 

I've heard that Willie Brown frequents there and to my surprise he came in and sat next to my table mid way through my lunch.
author: Sue L.

description:
My sister and I went here for her birthday dinner because they were offering the Dine About Town special, so we were inclined to like it because it was going to be special and cheap!  No no no.
The main problem was our waiter.  He started out great great great- we saw his tip going up.  My sister was torn on what she wanted, so he brought her out a tiny dish of the cassoulet (?) to try.  He also brought out some veggies (yummy and free!) even though my sister had also gotten fries. Great guy. But once we got our food, he disappeared.  Well, we saw him, but he didn't see us.  I was beginning to wonder if we had turned invisible, as even our water glasses sat empty.  
We had not yet ordered our dessert, and the busser boxed up our leftovers.  And we sat there.  Our waiter helped the tables on either side of us.  He saw our bag of takeaway and still didn't come over.  After he didn't come over for at least a half hour (I am so serious), my sister spoke with the manager and requested our dessert to go.  She apologized and was great, and we saw her talking to our waiter, but he was not at all apologetic.  He came over and dumped off our desserts, making it clear he wasn't speaking to us.  
When he brought the bill, he sort of spat out that he took 10% off since we had to wait so long.  
He was just baffling.  
And the food wasn't all that great, so I'm very glad we didn't have to pay full price.  
Bah.
author: Robin D.

description:
I've heard good things about this bistro and it is your place for french comfort food. I had a tiny bad experience which was a lipstick stained water glass. The waiter took it away and poured my water into a new glass =\ why he had not just handed me a new glass...i do not know. 
i ordered the CHICKEN POT PIE and it was very good. it had a nice flakey crust. the chicken, peas, potatoes were oozing with comfort. not too salty, not too bland, it was just right. the greens on the side were ordinary, so maybe for next time, a starter salad like their goat cheese cheese or butter lettuce will be make a nice addition.

Make reservation if having lunch here on a weekday. it can get very crowded.
author: Oanh N.

description: The staff here is very friendly here and I have been able to catch up on there many stories of growing up here so it is a relaxing place to stop off on a slow evening.  I have only had the wine here and they have a good choice of French wines at moderate prices.  One day I shall eat here if I stop through and am actually hungry, though I seem to prefer my liquid dinners anyhow.
author: Blake B.

description:
So, I go here for the drinks and the French fries.  

Usually, just the drinks but sometimes, if I haven't quite filled up on my starches in any of the Belden Place eateries I will order the fries.  Very good...crunchy, thin, hot fries!  

This is the perfect place to get a feel of "old" San Francisco.  Former politicians, society doyens, elite SF real estate agents, Olympic Club members...hell,  they all show up at one time or another and are pretty darned entertaining to watch.   But, in my opinion, they are welcoming and very friendly (especially after 9pm!!!!).

Gotta experience this place at least once.
author: Maggie K.

description: I love this restaurant and would give 5 stars but the tables are a bit close together for my liking -- but - maybe that is the way of French Bistros!!  I had a business lunch the other day with a client and had the Salad Nicoise which was wonderful.  I usually order the roast chicken which is also very good.  Very professionally operated with great food and excellent service.  Very easy to get in and out within a lunch hour as the food comes out quickly.
author: Vicki B.

description: I went here mostly because the restaurant is close to my apartment and opentable had a 1000-point.  I thought, why not.  As the rating shows, it was just A-OK.  The food, the wine, the service.  Nothing was bad...yet nothing really stood out besides the tasty free bread for an appetizer.  I was really surprised at the prices.  Most entrees were higher than I expected and should have been less.  On a positive note, you'll never have trouble getting a seat here...they always have room on opentable and it's never busy when I walk by
author: Joel F.

description:
A wonderful find.   Perfectly quaint and ideally suited for a comfortable weeknight dinner out.  The prices are fantastic, the selection on the menu is exactly what we expected, and the cassoulet was to die for.   

Looking for a place for a guaranteed good meal but you regret not making reservations anywhere?  This is your spot.

Wonderful french bistro cuisine
author: Jon S.

description: The place was very charming! Perfect for a date with your sweetie! I expected a fussy and upity staff and atmosphere but it was very artsy and casual. The staff was extremely hospitable! I got a red rose with our reservations, courtesy of my fiancee. The food was so tasty, worth the price we paid! Oh and try the cosmopolitan!!
author: Anne j.

description:
Ate here with my pops and wife on our weekend fam-stravaganza.  Le Central is a very FRENCH kind of place- not haute cuisine french or nouveau cuisine french but the kind of bistro you actually eat at in france because they don't have fast food restaurants and you don't feel like eating a crepe or baguette on the street like a hobo.

It's french down to the drinks- which are tiny- french down to the service which is occasionally attentive but often negligent.  If it wasn't for the english on the menu and being spoken in the restaurant, I could sworn I was in France.

That's not to say that this is a totally great restaurant- the food is super heavy and the prices are high for what you are eating.
author: scott p.

description:
I don't know where the previous reviewers ate but it does not ressemble the restaurant we just left.  We were greeted by a stony-faced maitre d' who never cracked a smile all night.  Our waiter thought he was doing us a favor by his presence--grumpy and unattentive.   Our waiter's attitude did not change when we ordered$120 worth of wine to start off.  On the positive side our table for six was ready when we arrived on time at 6.30 and a very pleasant hostess showed us to our table by the door!  
Tables were packed together to the point that we had to disturb customers on adjacent tables when were seated and left.
Things didn't improve with the food.  Two members of our group had one of the house specialities (casoulet)--very ordinary, as were the seaboat scallops. Our group has eaten at fine restaurants all over the world so we know good food when we taste it.  The roast chicken and the Boudin Noir (blood sausage) were good.
This may have been a good restaurant in the past but tonight it was very poor.  There are too many great places in the City to eat to even think about going back to Le Central.
author: don M.

description:
Le Central is one of those places you wish weren't located in one of the most touristy blocks in San Francisco (between Union Square and the Chinatown gates).  

These guys serve the best blood sausage in San Francisco, amazing fries, great cheese and wine selection, and good cocktails.  

I've eaten there maybe a half-dozen times, and received service completely commensurate with my level of dress.  I could almost smell the waiter's disdain when I walked in wearing a hoody and jeans; the same waiter treated me well when I wore work clothing (even if I got a little sloshed over the course of lunch...).  I don't hold this against them.  What I do find obnoxious they can't do much about: the restaurant on the bar side is narrow, and when you're seated with your back to the restaurant, the patrons and waiters constantly hit the back of your chair trying to pass.  It gets old.  If this place were bigger, less touristy, healthier and cheaper I'd go there more often...but then it wouldn't be le Central, and I probably wouldn't like it as much.
author: Phil K.

description:
I wish I had tried the cassoulet. I went in wanting to try the blood sausage but it wasn't on the menu that night, so I uncharacteristically played it safe with the roasted chicken. It was a disappointment-- a bit dry and overcooked. The french fries were pretty good, but oddly enough the most flavorful thing on my plate was the roasted tomato topped with crumbs and some cheese.
I heard good things about the steak across the table.
The atmosphere is pleasant and festive, and it was a nice meal, but the prices are pretty steep for what you're getting. 
And no Wilie Brown! But that's ok, I think I've seen enough of him for one lifetime.
author: Sara G.

description:
For very reasonably-priced French food in a relaxed but classy atmosphere, it's an excellent option. It's a convenient lunch option of mine, so I can't vouch for dinner, but I can say the following:

Salad nicoise - YUM!
Caesar salad - quite good
French onion soup - nice, but a bit too much cheese on top for my taste

Service is friendly - they greet me by name - but it can be a bit slow during peak hours.
author: Amy K.

description:
The crab cakes here are amazing - warm & toasty served over a plate of warm butter & white wine sauce... You must try this one! Friendly staff, and the occasional special SF elite guests sitting at the window table if you're lucky!

Great spot for an afternoon cocktail, steak and fires dinner or just a glass of French (or California) wine and a creme brulée dessert.
author: Brian B.

description: Boo! This was one of the first places I went to after moving to SF years ago. I gotta say...it's gone down hill. Sad because I used to love Le Central. Even the onion soup wasn't as good as I remember. Having one server is not ok - when you're charging as much as they do!!! Even if it a s week night an it's not packed! Le Sigh...
author: Marianne s.

description:
If your looking for a warm cozy French Bistro with ambiance, and good service Le Central is Perfect. Convenient location downtown draws locals, tourist and regulars a like. 

I recommend the tasty onion soup!
author: Shannon H.

description: Good but coulda been better. Very fine corn soup leads to decent but somewhat bland beef bourg. n very bland sides. Again def. way too pricey for the caliber of  old time bistro fare offered
author: Rick N.

description:
I use to frequent this restaurant a lot and have eaten a lot of the choices on the menu. I've eaten many lunches and dinners at this restaurant and I have thoroughly enjoyed every single meal I've had here.  At lunch you will typically see some of San Francisco's biggest bigwig's from Mayor Willie Brown, Wilkes Bashford, even the Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger.  

This place has the absolute best French fries you've ever tasted.  I would usually get the Filet Mignon with the Pepper Corn sauce and use that as dipping sauce for the fries, it is delicious.  Their Greek salad with Chicken is great for lunch. Actually all of their salads are great.  Their Shrimp Risotto was another alternative of mine.  It was always seasoned great and the risotto was great.  Their French Onion soup is always good any time of the year.  For dessert, I typically would get the tiramisu (which is still the best tiramisu, I have tasted ... and trust me I've had a lot of tiramisu).

Their servers and wait staff is very friendly and helpful.  The atmosphere is great.  It is a small bistro w/ nice dcor and usually has fresh flowers in both rooms, the bar side and the dining table side.  The small little chalkboards with the specials is a nice touch.  Parking may be difficult, but then again..... its San Francisco.

Overall if you're looking for a great experience in a nice French-bistro style restaurant, go to Le Central.
author: Jason S.

description: Everything was great.  Excellent service was timely but not rushed,  Varied and interesting menu choices.  Good selection of wine by the glass or bottle.  Food was excellent and beautifully presented.  We had fresh oysters on the half shell, a salad, and split an entree.  Our filet was cooked perfectly, split onto two plates in the kitchen and so beautifully presented that it appears the chef has a flair for design.  A memorable experience!
author: Jeff H.

description:
I came here with my wife about a year ago... we ate relatively well, by keeping it simple, and somewhat enjoyed it, although it can't be compared to Cafe Claude or other French restaurants in the city.
Tonight we went back with 2 more guests, and we ordered much more traditional French food: the cassoulet was tasteless, the chicken super-dry, the duck rillette like... out of a cheap can.
The place is very dirty; they sat us in the corner at the end of the dining room, and I felt that the whole surrounding was quite filthy as we were sitting down. After 20 minutes, an unidentified insect (I really don't want to know what it was!) started cruising on the wall right next to us. We called the waiter and... she asked us to catch it (!). They offered to give us free desserts on the house to apologize, but then they only took one dessert (the cheapest one) off the check.
Pretty disturbing and pathetic experience. Definitely a no-go-back.
author: Peppe R.

description:
Went here last night for my Dad's birthday dinner. Decided on this place because he used to work here in the pantry 24 years ago and hasnt been there since.

I called 2 days in advance for a reservation and got seated as soon as they looked in the book. BTW parking is horrible.

We were served by Jimmy, older Asian man. Wasn't too pleasant and it felt like we were a bother to him. seemed to be more into the bigger party and the smaller party on both sides of us. (8 on one side 2 on the other). But the Hispanic guys were on point! refilled water and drinks, bread, the whole 9 consistently.

The food was good. Everything we ordered was well presented and cooked to perfection. Def. recommend the roasted chicken w/ frites and the jumbo prawns with risotto.

for 4 people with appetizers, main dish, and dessert came out to 160 before tip. kinda pricey but worth seeing my dad happy. Would come again.
author: Edwin M.

description: So this week I've been trying more of the entree dishes and so far they have been delicious!  Both times I went for lunch this week the fish special was so good.  The butternut squash soup too was awesome with a beautiful presentation.
author: Ikey S.

description: Quite disappointed.  After a few meals at Scalas Bistro in the Sir Francis Drake Hotel, I requested a nice change of pace from the hotel concierge.   She recommends Le Central.  Bad call.   Food is not very inspirational, service seemed flustered and put out, and some mystery floaters in the water.   Not a great night.
author: Shad A.

description:
The tables on the bar side have the best views of the moving tableaux of SF's MoversandShakers, and, most importantly, easy access to hailing your waiter to bring a second martini.  

Le Central is always good for listening in on others' conversations and reconnecting with the Interior Carnivore - if you're a vegetarian or on a diet, just don't go there.  Monsieur Boeuf is the King and Madame Creme de Fromage is his consort here.

Youngin's groan at the 1970s era decor - get over it, kiddies.  You're not wearing the decor, for chrissakes.

The prices are a bit high for what it is, but stick with the onion soup and the endive salad (ah endive prices at the market make me want to scream), or splurg for a case of the gout and order the cassoulet (been cooking since the Carter Administration supposedly).  Just don't eat anything for 12 hours prior to the cassoulet: it's not for rookies.   

I don't recommend the pate - just save your pennies for your trip to France and get the real stuff.  The dessert tray has seen brighter days, too.  

The service is great at lunch (Louie is one of my fave waiters in SF).   Supper is a much more sedate crowd, but no less enjoyable.  Not the place for hard-core foodies or those on the extreme end of food fads, but fine for a dependable meal and civilized conversation levels.
author: Curtdude T.

description: We Had a reservation for 6:30, but somehow wound up an hour and a half early. Good thing too. Our waiter was Louie, sharp as a tack, saw us standing outside, ushered us in, gave us the best seat in the house and couldn't do enough for us. He's been with the restaurant since it opened and knows his stuff. The only problem is that he only works from 11:00 am to 6 pm. By getting there at 4:30 and eating early, Wow, what a treat. Would not have been the same meal without him. I had the cassoulet, in a word, perfection. My friend had the veal piccata, again, perfect. Don't get me started on the extras.........I haven't had such a good time and a good meal in years. Go early........grab Louie.......they're open all day. We'll be back...
author: Jeffrey C.

description: I wanted to like Le Central but was sorely disappointed. The food was very mediocre. The staff not much better. I'm generally not that critical but I was just kind of shocked at the whole experience (lunch).  Once you've eaten at a true French bistro this seems liked a charade.
author: D. H.

description: Overpriced and overrated would be the best ways for me to describe this spot. The food is fine -- nothing memorable -- but my overall experience was subpar. In fact, two stars is being a touch generous in my book. For lunch, at least. My boyfriend and I went in for lunch on a whim and were a bit surprised by how pricey their lunch menu was (they don't have a lunch-specific menu; it serves as a dinner menu, too). After a slight jaw drop at the $25+ lunch options, I finally settled on something small and my  boyfriend nabbed a Nicoise salad (around $20). Now, with the pricing and the intimate (read: tight) layout, I would think that the service would be top-notch to match. Nope. Not even close. I've experienced better service at Vietnamese restaurants where my server and I weren't even speaking the same language. Our server was far from welcoming and at times I felt like we were a burden for him. He was very blunt when answering my questions and seemed extremely perturbed by the fact that I ordered off of the starter menu for me meal. I mean, KILL ME! I wanted soup -- I'm sorry I didn't get the $25 catch of the day at 1PM! As soon as I ordered, his response went directly to the order minimum (apparently there's a $15 minimum per person... oops on my part for not reading the fine print): 'Well, I guess I'll let the minimum go since you're obviously not hungry.' Umm... okay, gee, thanks. While I do appreciate the gesture -- I really do! -- I felt bad the entire time and felt like a complete cheap ass for being called out. The waiter  plus the stuffy environment made our lunch very awkward. I would have opted for hole-in-the-wall pho or cheap-o sandwiches over this place. Unless something changes drastically, I can't imagine I'd ever go back or recommend this spot for lunch.
author: Shannon E.

description: beautifully presented food on a perfect afternoon lunch with my loved one =)
author: Linda A.

description: There were seven of us for dinner on Friday evening.  The appetizers we had--smoked salmon, clams bordelaise, Caesar salad, onion soup--were very good.  The entrees--from the cassoulet to the sea bass to the salmon to the steak--were terrific.  The service was impeccable without being intrusive.  The staff was very accommodating as we ate and talked for three hours.  It had been awhile since I ate here and we were glad we decided to try an old favorite.  We'll be back.
author: F B.

description: This is one of my husband and my favorite restaurants in the city.  I always have the scallops, which are always perfectly cooked; and my husband always has the chicken with french fries - the french fries are the best in town!  They also make a mean dirty martini.  We love the after work people who sit at the bar and become weirder as the evening progresses.  The only thing I would change is the fluorescent lighting that's covered by pretty stained glass.  (Keep the glass, change the lighting.)  The owner/manager and wait-staff are hilarious.  With them and the funny clientele, it's never the same place twice.
author: Ravena F.

description: What can you say about this place?  It's one of the standards in the City.  If all else fails, head to Le Central.  I have yet to find a more savory French fillet anywhere!  I have even sat by Herb's table a couple of times.
author: Joel C.

description: All the food was decent, cassoulet was quite delicious, but the price was excessive for what you get.  I think this is a result of being near Union Square and a bit of a tourist trap.  Not for locals.
author: Mike P.

description: The folks were quite CHARMING and the service was amazing. The folks here truly pulled out the stops to make us feel special. Definitely get the friend chicken!
author: BrasilPo P.

description:
I tried this place after reading an article in my local paper in Austin, TX.  The review was over 2 years old, and I guess have changed.  I ate there about a week before Christmas with a group of 9.  I had made the reservation, which was easy enough to make for a Wednesday night.  Immediately my impression was of a tired, old restaurant trying to hang out to its glory days.

The staff was extremely friendly and attentive.  I ordered a nightly special, pasta Bolognese.  I've had much better in Italian restaurants.  It was quite bland.  I should have ordered the cassoulet, their specialty.  Two others did, and I got to try it.  It was excellent.  It tasted like it had been cooking for hours, and it just melted in my mouth.

Someone had a fish dish, and they said it was pretty unremarkable.  To compare, I had eaten the year before at Café Claude, a couple of doors down.  That place definitely made me feel like I was in a French bistro.  The food at Le Central was several notches below that.

For a place on the coast I've never understood why the prices are so high on seafood -- and everything else for that matter.  I can get food that is far superior here at home, including seafood, for much lower prices.  I understand that cost of doing business is higher there, but still...

I'd recommend this place for a group, but for a more intimate dining experience and better food I'd go elsewhere.
author: Philip G.

description: A personal favorite provided that one sticks to the basics: filet mignon au poivre with fries and a salad nicoise to share, with the dishes plated for two people. Delicious and the creme brulee is excellent as well. Other dishes are a bit more "hit or miss" though these two treats always make it feel like a bit of France here in SF, especially on a rainy day.
author: Eric F.

description:
This the worst restaurant I ever had in my last 5 years... they label it as French !,  this is a lie, the food is cheap, poorly done.. they probably pay the people to say good thing about them, shame on you. 
We had a dinner, 7 peoples and everyone was like ..what ! , unbelievable , save your money and date ! look for a decent restaurant, avoid this SCAM.
author: Cheval M.

description: I have had better service from a taco john's drive thru and the food was just 'eh... Le Central is more Le Dreadful.
author: Steven K.

description: Consistently delicious food in a very comfortable setting!!!  Le Central has been a favorite for years and years!
author: Morgan A.

description: An old San Francisco standard that you really should not go to unless you are, well, old.   Most dishes are heavily laden with salt and butter.  The menu is famous for its Cassoulet, Escargot, Crab Cakes, etc.  Very heavy, very 1974.  On the plus side, if you go at the right time you can do some minor local celeb spotting - Wilkes Bashford, Willie Brown, Nancy Pelosi, among others.
author: Amme P.

description: Great Tiramisu and I dig the French Onion soup here. I must admit I have ordered a few things here that were less than great over the years....  but I do like the overall feel of the place for an intimate dinner. The whole power lunch crap that goes down here is laughable. Used to be Herb Caen's hangout, and the front booth bears a plaque in his name.. The service is pretty good, and it's usually not packed for a late supper....   good place to talk on a date.
author: Steven G.

description:
Le Central has gotten pounded!!! I went to Le Central after reading tons of not -so -great reviews and I think that places like Le Central, that is older, established restaurants are not appreciated for what they are. 
Le Central is not the newest or the flashies, chowhound food place. 
You are not going to find it on some feature in a San Fran magazine. 
Why go? Because it is a classic and I very much wish that Yelp reviews took more note of those places that have been around. 
I went with a party of four and I should note that we are young. We loved it. It was memorable and yet, so many places in SF are just a flash in my mind.
It is so classy and the maitre'd was in a lovely suit. Our wime choice was great and our entrees were delicious. The filet was excellent, my flat steak was really perfect. Goat cheese salad had lovely tomatoes.The chicken was so-so as was the risotto but when they brought the dessert cart out, well, I felt like a kid or as if I were in a dream. The food is not creative or new, but it is great and the ambience with the open windows is very romantic and quiet. This is a great date place. Le Central may not have latest but the food is good, the ambience is great (reminds me of a small village place in France) and deserves a visit.
author: Emily H.

description: Le Central came highly recommended from a friend so we walked in with high hopes. It was just as charming and quaint as expected. Our server was very helpful and suggested an haricot vert salad that was very refreshing. The fettucini bolognese was spicy, but comforting, and our greek salad was tasty too. Nothing revolutionary (i.e. vive la revolution!) but I will definitely go back when I'm craving the warmth of a traditional French bistro.
author: Amy J.

description: Okay, so Le Central is really nice, quant, good Martini's, attentive bar staff. However, I have an issue with the description on the menu. I had "Grilled Jumbo Prawns Saffron green pea risotto, tomato sauce" What I did get was 4 perfectly cooked jumbo prawns with rice with green peas, NOTHING close to risotto.. At $25 if it had been a proper risotto then I would have been, okay there was some work involved in the dish and perhaps justification of the cost of the entree, but it was plain old rice, and grilled prawns, no special talent needed to do this.. So basically it was like $5 a prawn and $5 for a portion of rice.. I know you are close to Union Square and get a lot of tourists (BTW, I am not a tourist, I might have an accent but I've lived here for 22 years). Set the expectations for the diner. I was expecting risotto, I got rice with peas. The Butter lettuce salad was good, true to the menu. Desert was good too, and true to the menu. For me, the heart of the night is the main dish and it really fell short. I did look at our neighbors who ordered the filet and it looked really good and they totally cleaned their plates.. I am up for trying this place again.. Perhaps I need to ask many questions before I make my decision on what I am going to order so I am not disappointed.
author: Martina L.

description: I was told I would see Willie here! Oh well, maybe next time. The service is relaxed and friendly and the food is dependably good, albeit expensive. The lunchtime crowd tends to be power lunch types and geriatrics, but perhaps to be expected for the neighborhood. The cold salmon is really good, as is the shrimp and risotto.
author: Jen L.

description: Great atmosphere and amazing happy hour! $1 oysters??? Yes please!!
author: Shermayne C.

description:
this place is old school frenchy.  think cigars and brandy.  willie brown also seems to frequent this place... although i don't think of him as either old school frenchy OR cigars and brandy.

their filet mignon is tasty.  if i feel like a good filet mignon, i'll come here.  also love their crab cakes.  all their food is very simple, but done well.  even their plain vegetables side taste awesome... but my favorite side is the gratin.

just because it's traditional french doesn't mean it's easy to do well; i've seen many places fail at just that.  this place is solid in my book.
author: Erika C.

description: Went here for a weekday lunch with the Moms and got seated immediately next to none other than former SF Mayor Willie Brown.  I think the hostess was diggin' my suit so much she felt compelled to seat us among the power executives.  Little did she know that I picked up that particular garment in Thailand for a price I won't disclose.  Anyway, my pre-conceived perception regarding French food and small portions was put to rest that day.  French Onion Soup was on point and the special of the day, a Braised Beef dish, was very satisfying in both quality and quantity.  To conclude my Le Central experience, Willie Brown shook my hand and gave me a pin promoting his new book.  Now that we're homies, I feel obligated to give him a plug.  "Basic Brown: My Life and Our Times", in stores now!
author: Brent N.

description: I can't say one good thing about this restaurant and can't for the life of me figure out what others have liked. The host was morose. The unintelligible manager was confrontational and the waitress was surly. The onion tart was a mass of gooey butter and flour with no texture whatsoever. The cassoulet was overcooked with soggy flavorless meat and the chicken frites arrived raw. After sending back the chicken it was returned burned to a rock-like texture. We also had to send the wine back as well and had everyone come over to our table to give us dirty looks.  The place was empty and we should have taken the hint. My friend grew up in France and I am a caterer.  Stay away and find someplace good to eat.
author: wwmb b.

description: A quintessential SF spot in a way that people have been going there for decades and some of the movers and shakers are there playing games and socializing... Arnold, current and former mayors, Wilkes B and similar crowd frequent this spot.  The food: delicious, the service: impeccable & classy, ambiance: suave, fancy...yet comfortable...  Go check it out!
author: M D.

description:
overrated.  
that's all.
so expensive. and none of it wowed me even remotely.
we saw brian boitano AND willie brown there and it still wasn't worth it.
author: K H.

description: This was a last minute choice as we had just arrived in San Francisco.  The food was wonderful and the staff helpful and friendly.  Definitely a keeper!
author: Alessandro I.

description: A wonderful neighborhood establishment for classic french cuisine. The atmosphere is cozy, the staff are quite helpful and the prices are reasonable enough to attract the locals as regulars.
author: Sara C.

description: Old San Francisco restaurant with an exceptional menu and wine list.  Their half chicken and pomme frits are the best you'll find anywhere.  Its a place where the local politicians eat.  In the old days you would find former mayor Willie Brown having a quiet lunch.  Its still great after all these years!
author: Ron C.

description: I'm an old soul so I like this place with an old fashioned feel.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Through a strange circumstance, our first and only meal from this place was takeout.  I felt pretty lame standing by the host's stand in shorts, waiting for plastic-bagged French food.  My lameness notwithstanding, the meal we ate at home 20 minutes later (!) was easily one of the best ones I've had in San Francisco.  How could a Filet Mignon delivered in plastic taste THAT GOOD?  I can only imagine what it would have been like in situ.  Likewise, my wife's chicken and frites were that old-world delicious that only places that have been open since the 70s can conjure up.  The raspberries for dessert melted wonderfully in my mouth.

When I first walked into Le Central, I pegged it as something of a tourist trap; if anything, it might be somewhat trapped by the tourists.  The locals need to give this place some respect, and certainly more of their business.  We will.
author: Rob P.

description: Classic French bistro.  I go back and forth between Le Central and its neighbor, Café de la Presse all the time.  Drinks at the bar or diner, I've never been disappointed here.
author: Kim M.

description: I know this is Willie Brown's favorite hang out for lunch and a power broker's haunt, but skip the menu and just go for the desserts.  The cassoulet was dry, over-cooked and ordinary.  Smoked trout appetizer  presented in a lackluster presentation, overloaded with red onions and the baked goat cheese appetizer with salad came with too much vinegar in the dressing and a stingy goat cheese cube.  (I know it's a French restaurant, but I also know a plate full of greens to distract any substantive elements when I see it.)  Desserts were great but left a $50 lunch tab plus tip with a promise not to return.
author: Eileen S.

description: I first came here for Bastille Day and had really good French onion soup and  escargots.  This time we sat at the table where Herb Caen used to sit and had the French onion soup, butter lettuce salad, tomato and anchovy salad, and the smoked trout plate, along with some stiff drinks and ending off with the creme caramel and chocolate pot de creme.  Like J said, just basic ingredients, but all prepared correctly.  Staff was very nice, friendly and attentive.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Yup Dave the bartender is the best!   I also love the atmosphere of the place.  Really quaint.
author: Jean K.

description: So-so place.   Nothing blew me away about this place.  The beet salad was pretty tasty but nothing to write home about.
author: Chaz N.

description: old school service, french menu...great celery ravigote!
author: Margaret L.

description: I go here for the escargot (very traditional with loads of butter and garlic versus the nonsense some restaurants come up with for this dish).  The french onion is excellent.  The entrees can be hit or miss.  If you like traditional french food with no twists, this is the best place in town for that.
author: S. C.

description: I came here for lunch awhile back with some colleagues. It's very french - meaning the crusted mahi mahi that i ordered came laden with a rich, heavy cream sauce and accompanied with creamed spinach. It wasn't bad, but at $25 I found it a little too heavy on both the wallet as well as the stomach for just lunch.
author: Amy H.

description: Classic SF bistro that is mostly French cuisine.  I think it has been around for at least 30 years.  Sit on the bar side  if you can.  I typically come here in the late afternoons when the crowds thin out (don't care about the who's who who eat here and wouldn't recognize them anyhow).  Over the last several years it seemed like the service and food was going downhill but recently had a great lunch.  Cold salmon and the salad nicoise (?sp) were very good.  Service was good.  Would have given it 3 stars but since it seemed to be improving I bumped it to 4 and will obviously return.  someone else mentioned possible new owners, I don't know about that but something seemed different and potentially for the better.
author: Damon S.

description: This place is a quaint, cozy San Francisco tradition. You can come in here for food and a drink to warm up from the fog outside, escape the heat, or shelter from the rain. The food here is the traditional French Bistro and is delicious. I usually sit at the bar and eat and drink. The waiters and bartenders are friendly and know the ins and outs of the cuisine and wine pairings.
author: Vanessa C.

description: I used to like this place... not so much anymore... I had a bad experience last time I went there; I was with a group of friends, a group of 6+ so yes they included the 18%, fine... what was not so cool is that they charged each single of us who paid with a credit card an additional 18% tip even though we mentioned $0 as the additional tip on the receipt... mistake? maybe yes, maybe not... I'd leave one star for the food that was quite good.
author: Jean-Paul S.

description: I give this restaurant three stars for one reason only: the food was pretty damn good.  The service on the other hand was awful.  Our waitress took about 15 minutes to come to the table (the busboy had already given us bread, but we didn't have anything to drink), and was as personable as wet cardboard.  She didn't ask if we had questions or make any suggestions as to what we should order as first time diners.  The appetizer arrived and instead of the french onion soup I ordered I was presented with a crab cake.  I alerted her to the error and decided just to eat the crab cake, which was delicious, instead of wait for her to remedy the situation.  She apologized but once again the lack of any real concern showed through.  My boyfriend ordered the cheese plate which was tasty but the neighboring table had to supply him with a piece of bread as our waitress never came back to check on us, although he attempted to make eye contact with her repeatedly.  It was as though she was blatantly ignoring us!  Our filet mignons with veggies were cooked properly and very good.  I had a coke to drink and after it sat empty for 10 minutes my boyfriend was finally able to flag the waitress down to ask for another.  I work in a fine dining restaurant in another state and I completely understand how it feels to be weeded, but a smile and genuine concern for my customers always goes a long way.  The tip, needless to say, was the worst I've ever given any server in the last 15 years.
author: Meg D.

description: The place for french onion soup on a cold day. Menu proally hasn't been too updated the last ten years and Willie B. loves this place to hob nob w. Arnold S. They have no taste...in old style food.
author: miriam b.

description:
Not impressed - probably will never go back given the dining options in San Francisco.  For the price, try Absinthe on Hayes.

The food was just okay.  Nothing to write home about.  I had the onion soup, caprese salad, and filet mignon - the soup lacked flavor, the tomatoes tasted like safeway, steam-ripened delights and it felt like the kitchen was trying to hide the fact that the ingredients were cheap by burying them in mediocre salad dressing.  The filet was nothing special.  The presentation was laughable - it felt like Joe's at Westlake.

Generally an older crowd.   The tables are crowded together, so you're literally sitting inches away from the people next to you.  On the night we went out, my wife and I were enjoying ourselves and our own conversation, but by the end of the night, we found ourselves having to apologize to the people next to us - a pretentious, older (50+), racist (anti-german) french couple sitting next to us - because they thought we were being too loud and gesturing too flamboyantly.

Given the crowded placement of the tables, the mediocre food, and buzz killing neighbors we had the night we were there - I have to give this place 2-stars....
author: Justin V.

description:
Great little French bistro in the heart of SF. The menu is limited, but specials make up for it. Good place for a tasty taste of French food at an affordable-level.

I'm a suspicious as to whether the by-the-glass Bordeaux was really a Bordeaux or not.
author: andy s.

description: Whenever I get a need for REAL French food, I go to Le Central.  It reminds me so much of the bistros I visit whenever I am in France.  A true delight in the City.  The food is excellent and the staff is very friendly and helpful.
author: Danny M.

description: While the food is good, I also enjoy the atmosphere. It's clubby without the pretension. Louie the waitperson is fantastic, and it's fun watching the San Francisco Swells in their Brioni/ Chanel best shmooze and gamble. Have some fries and enjoy the show!
author: Fawn L.

description:
Steak tartare the best in the city as well the french onion soup. .
keep up the good work
author: susan m.

description: Le Central is a perfect example of a small French bistro you'd find in Paris or the nice part of any random French town. The food is very good for bistro standards and attracts a high-end clientele during the week's lunch hours. However, lunch on weekends is very slow and perfect for a quite meal.
author: Guillaume J.

description: Le Central was good.  The entree was amazing, it was one of the daily specials, a seabass.  That I would highly recommend that as well as the frites (fries).  But the creme brulee was just ok.  It was kind of bland and very eggy, but the rest of the meal was great.  The service was also very good, the wait staff was very attentive.  The prices were good not great.  Try it for yourself...
author: Brad T.

description: Food is great, and Willie Brown is a staple.  I'd recommend this restaurant for a casual lunch close to the financial district and shopping.
author: Matt W.

description: a fantastic french bistro.  i had steak tartare for the first time, and it was great.  my husband had the lamb, which was also wonderful.  and, i met willie brown there, the waiter introduced me!  it is always great to have a high budge meal where the waiters are not snobby.
author: charlene l.

description: It seems Le Central isn't quite hitting it with the younger crowd... I've gone here three times, with my best friend and her parents, before a show at the GG Theater. (Years ago, right?) Personally, I've NEVER had a bad experience here, and the food I've ordered has been very good. The service is hilarious if you don't take the waiters seriously! I never do. When we were there last we saw Maggie Scura. Cracked me up! She looked exactly like she did on TV years ago! We've seen the mayor W. Brown, too. I don't know. It's an old SF institution... I dig it for the experience, and honestly, I've always had good food or I wouldn't come back. You just have to know what to order. (Not the rabbit, apparently...) I wish I could remember what I enjoyed the most, but other than the creme brulee, I'm drawing a blank. I've eaten at too many French restaurants to keep the menus straight unless I've just eaten there. I'll post an addendum next chance I get because I want to take my husband there and see what he thinks....
author: Shari D.

description: For a great stand by, solid French meal, nothing fancy and not too expensive  and not trendy but comfortable, Le Central is quite dependable. We had dinner last night with a friend visiting from NYC. Great poached salmon and great flank steak with frittes. Steak tartare and buter lettuce salad to start were all superb. Salad a little over dressed but then again its not Bosnia. Wine list is a bit varied but from a consistency standpoint - Le Central is always there for a good dinner. Service was pleasant and efficient. They give you the LARGEST chunk of butter with your bread - that has got to be worth something
author: greg o.

description: bonjour everyone....just found the best onion soup...if u like cheese...this is the one to order.....  bon apetite
author: Mee-stique K.

description: I ate dinner here at the bar the other night, food was great, the bartender was fantastic, I think his name was Dave, and he was cute too ;)
author: blah k.

description: Over-priced, over-hyped (just cuz SF poloticos go there dosen't mean the food is good!) Very disappointing food esp the Casoulet though the pomme de frites are tasty!
author: dawn w.

description: The Scallops Provencal  - awesome! And the staff was very nice! Charlie, the man who greets you when you come in, did something extra special for me - he held on to a parking space right by the restaurant and guided me by phone as I was just a few blocks away! I have never had such kindness extended to me by a restaurant person! The restaurant is an easy walking distance to the Theater District and Union Square. This was my 1st time there and I will go back - many good choices on the menu. Nice wine, too. Will be added to my fav's.
author: Doris D.

description: Our recent visit was truly a bad dining experience. I think that the quality has plummetted, perhaps its 'new ownership,' not the original team. We were a group of 4 sitting in the back room. On the banquette at a table next to us was a man and woman 'couple' who were amorous in an appallingly inappropriate plublic manner. Our group is in our 40's and no prudes, but it was an uncomfortable experience, one that we felt discomfort not only for ourselves but for those around us also who clearly had an issue with this inappropriate behavior in a public setting. It was also a disappointment that management didn't address this situation and seemed to ignore the comfort of their guests. I would never bring my parents to this place after witnessing that. On top of that, our server, and thus service, was poor: slow, forgetful, and usually absent. The food was forgettable, I had casoulet, which was just mediocre, lacking in flavor, I have had much much better elsewhere (eg., Jeanty at Jacks). I would be disinclined to suggest Le Central to my parents - or my friends - in the future- but i would suggest they go to any of the better french restaraunts in town, Jeanty's, Cafe Claude, Fringale, etc..
author: Mike P.

description: On 1/26/10 a friend and I had dinner here and I must agree with some of the other reviews that the place is not worth the money for the quality of the menu items. My filet with the peppercorn sauce was just OK but the sauce drowned out the flavor of the meat. The onion soup was very tasty however and normally I would give more stars but the attitude of the waiter controls the number of stars in this case. The place was virtually empty and yet the service was very poor with the waiter having an attitude of boredom as if he was  bothered having to wait on us. I had read they were participating in the " dine about town' pre fixed dinner plan and yet when I asked about this they were somewhat aloof and not eager to provide any information about this program.When we did get that ' dine about town ' menu he started to grab our regular menus away with a huffy attitude. Although we did not select that pre fixed menu it would have been the smarter thing to do since the value for the regular ala carte entrees was just not there. Maybe if the wait staff's attitude was a bit more friendly they would have more than 3 tables full on a week day night !
author: Ann B.
